TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise under standing order 95 to bring to the attention of the House a matter of privilege. The matter concerns two articles dealing with the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. One article is by Martin Daly in the Melbourne Sunday Herald on 9 September and is headed `Migrant Amnesty Proposals Give Hope to 20,000'. The other article is by Michael Millett in the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday, 10 September, and is headed `Call to Ease Law on Illegal Migrants'.

SPEECH.PARA: The House of Representatives Practice at page 713 states that the evidence taken by any select committee and documents presented to and proceedings and reports of such committees which have not been reported to the House shall not, unless authorised by the House, be disclosed or published by any committee member or by any other persons. It is clear to me that both articles reveal either that the authors have seen confidential draft reports of the Committee or have been informed of the private deliberations of the Committee.

In the time since the articles were published, and given that the Committee has been finalising its report for presentation today, I have not been able to establish the sources of these articles. As a result of the articles, serious concern has been created in the community and false expectations have been created in relation to the possibilities of an amnesty which, as honourable members will see when the report is presented later today, is misleading and a misrepresentation of the Committee's recommendations.

I raise the matter for your consideration now, Mr Speaker, because I am extremely concerned that the Committee's private deliberations and/or its draft report have not been kept confidential. I understand that under the Standing Orders matters of privilege must be raised at the first opportunity. The Melbourne Sunday Herald is published by Herald and Weekly Times Ltd, Flinders Street, Melbourne, and the Sydney Morning Herald by John Fairfax and Sons of Jones Street, Broadway.

I present copies of the articles in question and I ask you, Mr Speaker, to consider giving precedence to a motion so that the issue can be referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Privileges for investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I will give consideration to the matters raised by the honourable member for Calwell and report to the House at a later hour today.

—I refer the Prime Minister to his assertion last Sunday that `I really know how to run this and lead this Labor Party. I just operate quietly behind the scenes'. Can the Prime Minister, therefore, inform the House why he has so continuously lent public support to the Beazley megacom option while acknowledging in the Cabinet room that it is an inferior proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Leader of the Opposition for his question. I have made no apology at any stage of this ongoing debate for the processes that have been employed within the Australian Labor Party. We have been the party in government which has been prepared to tackle the very difficult issues of micro-economic reform. I remind the Leader of the Opposition that my challenge, made at the time of the last election, remains unanswered. I asked him or anyone behind or around him then to nominate any period of conservative government which came within a bull's roar of the record of achievement in micro-economic reform of this Government. That challenge remains unanswered because it is unanswerable.

ANSWER.PARA: In this process of undertaking what the conservatives never had the guts to do we have been prepared within our Party to undertake open discussion. When we talked about an issue such as introducing competition into the area of telecommunications, it was inevitable that there were going to be deep feelings and differences of opinion within our Party. I said appropriately the other day that I had my way of leading this Party, and I guess that in the end I would say to honourable members opposite, including the present Leader and the other two behind him whom I have met and dealt with, that the record of leadership of the Labor Party since 1983 is best tested by looking at who has got the runs on the board.

I have continued in that way on this important issue. I have encouraged debate and discussion and I have recognised, as Minister Beazley has recognised, the indisputable fact that no-one can assert that any particular model has 100 per cent of all the benefits and lacks all of the disadvantages.

There are certain features of competition based on an OTC model which have their attractions and to which I have referred. Let me say that there would also be distinct costs in using OTC. The bene- fits of OTC are based on OTC's know- ledge of the Australian market. But the important thing to notice under the proposal that the Cabinet has now endorsed is that OTC will not be lost to the Australian people; its values and its skills will be retained in public ownership and it will remain a highly competitive force in one of the most important markets for telecommunications, and that is of course our link with the rest of the world.

Also, it should be understood that it will serve another invaluable purpose, and that is as an incentive to Telecom to get its interconnect operation done right and get it done soon. All overseas experience, particularly in the United States, if I may say so, shows the desperate need for an incumbent monopolist to have a stake in getting competition started. OTC will certainly be that stake for Telecom. Those are the considerations that I regard as relevant to the question that has been asked by the Leader of the Opposition.

I must say in conclusion that the hypocrisy of the approach of the Leader of the Opposition on this matter is mind-boggling. We understand that what the Leader of the Opposition is suggesting is that if one has an unqualified view as to what is the right policy position the responsibility of leadership is to push that and to push it despite the pressures one may face. I have answered in this case why we have taken the position we have in regard to Telecom. For this man opposite, this Leader of the Opposition, to adopt this position is the height of hypocrisy. In this place I have indicated what the clear position of the Leader of the Opposition was, when he was an untainted academic, on a fundamental issue of policy-taxation. He was asked on 3 August 1987 what his position was on capital gains and fringe benefits taxes. What he had to say then-and this is the Leader of the Opposition who asks that leadership be followed through-was this: `I'd go for near uniform taxation of all forms of income'.

In other words, before the bully boys of the Liberal Party, the ones behind the scenes who have got the power and tell the leaders what to do, had got at him he had a clear and unequivocal view of what the responsibility was in this matter; that is, that he would tax capital gains the same as income tax. When it gets to the position of leadership, when he is there and has the opportunity to give leadership on a fundamental issue of taxation, what does he do? When the bully boys of the Liberal Party say `No capital gains tax', this Leader says, `Yes, sir, no capital gains tax'. It did not come too difficult for him because, as a man of considerable holdings of real property and personal property, it was very convenient to forget what he had thought was the real position.

So do not let this Leader of the Opposition talk about the responsibility of leadership. On a fundamental issue of taxation reform, when he knew what the right position was, instead of providing his Party with leadership, he turned around to the bully boys of the Liberal Party and said, `Okay, if there is to be no capital gains tax I will lie down'. He lay down and in so doing he forfeited any claim to decent leadership and to having any integrity whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House of progress in Australia's efforts to encourage an end to the Cambodian dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government and, I believe, the people of Australia, I welcome wholeheartedly the agreement reached by the Cambodian factions in Jakarta last night to accept the United Nations Security Council framework for peace in Indo-China. I trust that, in expressing that welcome on behalf of the Government, I am speaking for all members of this House because that decision taken in Jakarta last night represents the greatest opportunity yet for an end to what has been this continuing saga of tragedy, conflict and suffering of the Cambodian people.

ANSWER.PARA: Last night the Cambodian parties agreed, firstly, on the formation of a supreme national council, the SNC, and, importantly, that that SNC will embody the sovereignty of Cambodia. Secondly, the SNC will occupy the Cambodian seat at the United Nations and, most importantly for current purposes, the SNC will delegate to the United Nations all the powers necessary to implement a comprehensive peace agreement, including the conduct of free and fair elections and the general administration of Cambodia. It is quite clear, now that this major decision has been made and agreement reached to this point, that a considerable amount of detail and much hard work remains to be done in order to bring the process to ultimate fruition. But there is no doubt that the Jakarta meeting and the decision made there are crucial for this further process to go forward.

Australia is not automatically committed to the deployment of Australian forces as part of the United Nations role that will be involved, but I have indicated previously, and I do so again, that Australia will be prepared to make a major contribution to a United Nations presence in Cambodia in the transitional period which is envisaged under that decision. Of course, the size and nature of that contribution will depend on the United Nations requirements as determined by the Secretary-General and the provisions of the final settlement.

Finally, I trust that all honourable members-not only those on this side of the House-will join me in applauding the magnificent contribution that has been made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans. Senator Evans took the initiative on this issue and there is a universal recognition by all participants in this process-not only by those directly involved in Cambodia but by the other nations; the Association of South East Asian Nations, the European nations, the United States and the permanent five-that the permanent five framework which was adopted at the Jakarta meeting last night is based upon the work put forward by Australia through its Foreign Minister. Therefore, the whole of Australia, irrespective of people's political affiliations, should join, with great joy, in applauding the magnificent work that has been done by Australia's Foreign Minister.

That initiative and concept which flowed from the Australian Foreign Minister has been given effect to by the tremendous work undertaken by officials of our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Many of those officials have been involved in the hard slogging, shuttle diplomacy within Asia, Europe, the United States and the United Nations. I pay tribute to them all but most particularly to the work done by Mr Michael Costello.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Treasurer. By way of background, the Treasurer would have seen in the report on mobile telephones by the Australian Telecommunications Authority, Austel, its view that where there is a duopoly of only two competitors in a market, monopoly prices are still charged, no real choice is offered to the consumer and there is no incentive to adopt new technologies and minimise costs. The Treasurer would also have seen that Austel then argued that more competitors produce greater benefits in terms of efficiency, price, product and service. In the light of that, I ask the Treasurer: Is Austel right on its economic arguments against duopolies and in favour of greater competition? If so, why is the Australian economy not to get the full benefits of competition in telecommunications?

—The Government has not reached a final conclusion on the particular recommendations of Austel, so one cannot be clear as to what competitive outcomes are likely to emerge until that decision has been made. As to the more general point about duopolies and competition, we could have a debate here all afternoon about that. We could perhaps start by the coalition telling us why it was so happy to sit with monopolies, let alone duopolies, for years particularly in telecommunications and why it was so keen to re-establish a duopoly in airlines just before the 1983 election.

—Did the Minister for Land Transport meet with his State and Territory transport colleagues in Hobart on 7 September 1990? Was consideration given to the establishment of a national rail freight corporation? What was the result of these discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the question is yes, I did meet last Friday in Hobart with the State transport Ministers. The propositions that were put before the State transport Ministers probably represented some of the most substantial proposals that State transport Ministers have ever given consideration to. One of those, as indicated by the question asked by the honourable member for Port Adelaide, is the question of the proposed national rail freight corporation.

ANSWER.PARA: I was delighted with the way in which the State Ministers responded, although they have from time to time indicated some degrees of concern-and some of those are continuing. I have assured them their concerns will be resolved in the process of negotiations and the discussions which will take place as a result of the decision to establish a task force of officials from both the Federal Government and each of the State governments. The task force will be appointed under an independent chairman to ensure that each of the States can be satisfied that it will be able to participate appropriately.

The intention is that we try to get as many of the principles together for the proposed national rail freight corporation by the end of this year. We will then call a special meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council, consisting of both the State transport Ministers and me, at the end of January to give further consideration to the issue.

I would like to emphasise this point: I said that it was one of the most important propositions taken before State transport Ministers since Federation-probably in the last 100 years, as the Leader of the National Party would concede because of his own interest in the development of rail. It has been estimated that if we were able to get a corporation of the kind suggested up and running and we required it to operate on a very firm, positive, commercial basis, it would be possible for it to make a contribution to Australia's gross domestic product of something like $1.4 billion every year. That would continue year after year.

Not only that, but if we were able to do it the States and State taxpayers by about 1993-94 would benefit to the extent of something like $375m every year. I think we ignore possibilities of that kind to our peril.

I would like to emphasise something else in connection with this. Some people may have had some reservations about whether rail will be or should be able to compete effectively against road transport at the present time. Because of the particular interest of the honourable member for Melbourne Ports in the successful operations of Australian National (AN), I point out that it has just recently declared-

TALK.START.PARA: —What has Melbourne Ports got to do with it?
—Well, AN is involved in intersystem freight.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Adelaide ports, thank you. Any of the ports would have plenty to do with rail. That is one of the modal interfaces that we are giving consideration to.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-It's Port Adelaide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian National, the Commonwealth Government railway system, as you know, Mr Speaker, just announced a profit for the last financial year in excess of $8m. On its freight division last year there was a profit of $11m. That compares with $9m the year before and represents the fourth consecutive year in which AN has made a profit on the interstate freight movement.

ANSWER.PARA: The only State system which has been able to do that is the Western Australian system. It made a profit of about $2m last year. So it indicates that rail can become competitive. If we approach it commercially, if we get together systems of the kind we need, we will be able to operate rail commercially with benefits to State taxpayers and the national economy of the dimensions that I have indicated.

The deficit on AN's passenger services was reduced by something approaching $3m with the result that the annual deficit now is substantially lower than it was before. It was hoped that it would be able to cut even on Tasrail's operations. I am sure it is of particular interest to those honourable members who come from Tasmania that the deficit the previous year was about $4m; last year it made a profit of $60,000. I know that is not very substantial, but it indicates very clearly and positively that if we are prepared to take the initiatives that are obviously necessary in connection with rail, then we can get rail to a position where it will be able to satisfy and fulfil the types of requirements that should be made for rail. That is important for Australia. It is important to the effectiveness and success with which the whole land transport system can operate. I appreciate the question and I understand the honourable member's interest in it because he represents that industry and those people very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. It is asked in token of the Prime Minister's great affection for political history in this country. I remind the Prime Minister that the special national conference of his Party on privatisation is to be held almost five years to the day after his own inaugural `Light on the Hill' oration at Bathurst in September 1985 when he exhorted his Party members to keep fresh and green the memory, the example and the experience of the late Ben Chifley by totally opposing the then policies of the Opposition to privatise, in whole or in part, Australian Airlines, Qantas, the Commonwealth Bank and Telecom. Now that the Prime Minister has been forced to accept, however inadequately, the essential logic of what the Liberal and National parties asserted at least five years ago, how does he justify to the Australian people his blatant political opportunism then and also the lost opportunity over the last five years to bring about major structural changes with bipartisan support in areas which he will undoubtedly tell his Party's conference in two weeks time must be tackled if the government is to have a remotely credible micro-economic reform agenda?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. I preface my remarks by expressing the hope that he does not think that history began just five years ago. If we are going to have an historical exercise, let us have a brief one. If we started our historical exercise in 1949, we would come to the conclusion that between 1949 and 1990 the honourable gentleman and his--
—That is our policy--

—Does the honourable member opposite want to slice up history? Does he not want to look at history? For the greater part of the period since 1949 he and his mob have been sitting on this side of the chamber, with the responsibility for running this country and undertaking any degree of micro-economic reform his Party thought was necessary. In the whole of that period his Party's record was zilch.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member mentioned airlines. Who was the initiator of the duopoly in the airlines industry? Who fought all the way through to keep that duopoly, a licence to print money for one? It was those opposite. In all that period when the honourable member for Bennelong was the Treasurer and had the opportunity to do something about the airline industry, he protected that duopoly. He did not change his thinking at all, he did not develop; he sat there rooted in the conviction that no change was required to what had been done by his predecessors since 1949. In that whole seven-year period when the honourable member's Party was in office, including the time when his Party had control of the Senate, when he could have undertaken any micro-economic reform he wanted in this country, his record was appalling. He did nothing. I have not just stayed rooted in one position.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—Many philosophers say that the mark of a hopeless individual is that that person is not prepared to develop his thinking. I stand before this House and openly acknowledge that in the period since I have been Prime Minister, when I have had the responsibility of leading this country and facing up to the challenges of the 1980s and 1990s, I have understood that some of the positions and the attitudes of the past are not appropriate to the challenges of today and tomorrow. I have been prepared to change my thinking.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not stand before this House and apologise for the fact that I understand that, as we go into the final decade of the twentieth century, the attitudes and the assumptions that were formulated 20 or 30 years ago are not the most appropriate. I stand here before this House and say, as I have said publicly elsewhere, that it is necessary to change our thinking to meet the challenges of time. This side of the House has been prepared, as I say, not to stay rooted in the past and claim that what was good enough then is good enough today. Unfortunately, true to their conservative brand, those opposite cannot change their thinking. In relation to the airlines, the waterfront and all the other areas that were crying out for micro-economic reform, they were not prepared to do so. They went through seven years of office and brought in no change.

We have come to office and faced up to the responsibilities. We have understood that we have had to say to our Party that the positions we have had in the past are not necessarily the right positions for Australia today if we are going to take Australia best equipped into the twenty-first century.

I have no compunction whatsoever in standing before this House and saying yes, I have developed my thinking and changed my position in certain respects because I believe that the attitudes of the past are not appropriate for the present or the future. I make no apologies for that. The great tragedy is that those who are bound by ideology, those who sit on the other side of the House, neither had the courage in office to change nor have the imagination now to be relevant.

I am confident that when I go before the members of my Party on 24 September they will respond to the challenge that I and my Cabinet colleagues put to them-that we have to be prepared to change. It will not be a matter of apologising and saying that we had a different view before because the precise point I will be putting to them is that the point and the position we had before are not appropriate to the present and that the interests of this country demand change.

The difference between us will be one of ideology. Our change will be based upon the proposition that we need to have competition in the telecommunications area, including retaining a fully publicly owned telecommunications facility. That will distinguish us from the Opposition. As we go through the period of this Parliament and up to the next election it is a fight that I will be looking forward to having. It will be a fight about which the Government side will say that the proper development of telecommunications in this country, the proper protection of Australian citizens, requires competition and, within a competitive framework, it requires a fully publicly owned internationally and domestically operating telecommunications facility.

Against that position of reality and responsibility towards the welfare of this country we will be facing ideologues who have no interest in the ordinary people of this country. They will just engage in a $20 billion fire sale to hand over the whole of the telecommunications industry to the private sector. The Opposition will not have any concern for retaining a framework which will look after the interests of ordinary consumers.

I tell the present Leader of the Opposition, the ex-Leader of the Opposition and the whole of the Opposition that that is a fight that we are looking forward to. We have had our arguments within our Party but when we have finished our position out of the conference it is certain that the Labor Government will be standing for a telecommunications industry in which there is a fully publicly owned telecommunications facility. That will be against the Opposition's position, which will be to flog off the whole of the telecommunications industry to the private sector, which would have one concern and one concern only, that is, the maximisation of private profit. As I said, that is a fight that I am looking forward to; it is a fight we will win.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services explain the benefits that will flow to families from changes to child-care as announced in the Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Forde for her question. The question she has put before the House basically draws to our attention the most significant child-care expansion in the history of this country. This year the Commonwealth is spending an extra $75m and over the next three years an additional $400m. In three years time we will be spending twice as much on child-care as we are spending now. This brings quite clearly to the public focus the fact that this Government has implemented its commitment to provide this massive shift in the provision of social infrastructure through child-care. As a result of this unprecedented growth in child-care, aged care, medical and pharmaceuticals, family allowance supplement and employment support, and despite the very tight fiscal conditions that we operate under, this Government has provided that infrastructure for the ordinary family.

ANSWER.PARA: In child-care we see it exemplified in three particular ways: through accessibility, affordability and, very importantly, equality. By 1995-96 the changes that have been put into place now will mean that there will be a quarter of a million child-care places in Australia. That is more than double what we have now and about three times what we had when this Government came to office.

When it comes to the question of affordability, we want to make sure that people, no matter what their income as long as they need that child-care, should be able to afford it. Unlike the United States and Britain, where child-care is beyond the reach of normal ordinary working families, in this country child-care will be accessible and affordable. Under the new fee relief arrangements up to 125,000 families will benefit from the more generous fee relief system introduced in this Budget. Their parents will get some help with their fees on incomes up to $56,200 if they have one child in care. From 1 October, for parents who are earning $280 a week now, the fee relief ceiling will be lifted to $370 a week. They will get up to $85 a week for 50 hours of care. From 1 January 1991 parents with children in approved commercial centres will get help with their fees for the first time. I think that is a very important issue of equity.

In contrast, the Opposition's tax rebate policy would do little but inflate prices in a market where the demand is so strong. It would do very little about supply. In fact, the costs would blow out. That has been shown to be the fact in the United States, for example, where in 1980 the Government spent $956m on its tax rebate for child-care. That blew out to $3.4 billion in 1986, a massive increase in expenditure without really influencing the supply.

I am glad that the honourable member for Forde has asked this question because she has done a tremendous job over the last couple of months in addressing the very important issue of the extension of fee relief to people with children in commercial care. Very importantly, through a committee representing commercial as well as community interests and unions that she has brought together, she is addressing the issue of quality. The recommendations that the honourable member for Forde is bringing together with the work of that committee show a tremendous spirit of consensus in this area that will certainly in a very short period to come-in a matter of months-start to show benefit in the quality of child-care as well as affordability and accessibility for many thousands of Australian families.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Prime Minister is in two parts. I ask whether he agrees with the following statement by the Chairman of the Industry Commission, Mr Tony Cole:

QUESTION.PARA: In the year in which we finally dismantle the domestic two airline agreement and all the inefficiencies that has delivered, it would be ironic if we were to plunge ourselves into another closed system of regulated duopoly in telecommunications.
In fact, is it correct that all senior economic Ministers oppose the megacom option finally agreed to by Cabinet?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that the decision that has been taken would not fit the model that is alleged to have been referred to by Tony Cole, the head of the Industry Commission. We will see when the legislation comes into this place that that is the case. I have no reason to make any further comment on what was said in regard to the first part of the question.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the second part of the question, I am obviously, as would be expected, not going to go into the details of the Cabinet discussion on this matter. I simply say, in elaborating slightly on what I said before, that in the Cabinet, as throughout my Party, there has been detailed discussion, debate and argument. First, what united the Cabinet was the commitment to having an effective, competitive position in the telecommunications industry. Second, we were united in our position that in a competitive framework there should be retained, in full public ownership, a telecommunications facility which operates internationally and domestically.

It is no secret that in terms of those two considerations which united the Cabinet, there was some difference of view as to how those objectives may best be met. All I can say is that I am totally confident, as one who was engaged fully in that debate and in looking at alternatives, that those two objectives will be totally met. That is, when the legislation is passed Australia will have one of the most competitive telecommunications industries in the world. Having what are now OTC and Telecom combined will not be an aberration but will represent what operates in virtually every other country in the world, where there is one facility operating both the international and domestic aspects of the telecommunications enterprise. There seems to be some misunderstanding in the minds of the members of the Opposition and many commentators that what is being talked about here by having OTC and Telecom together is some sort of an aberration when in fact the truth is that having them separated has been an aberration in terms of international comparison.

I conclude by saying that I am totally confident that when the legislation is passed, Australia will have the benefit, firstly, of one of the most effectively competitive telecommunications industries in the world, and secondly and importantly, in terms of the Australian tradition that we will continue to defend, a significant part of that effective, competitive telecommunication industry will be a fully publicly-owned facility.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health and relates to the bone marrow register announced in the Budget. Could the Minister inform the Parliament what progress has been made on this initiative and how it will improve the chances of survival of many leukaemia sufferers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As many honourable members would be aware, transplantation of bone marrow is currently the only curative therapy available for a number of diseases of bone marrow, including severe aplastic anaemia and chronic myeloid leukaemia. For many people in need of a bone marrow transplant who have been unable to find a compatible donor among relatives, the only hope had been a search of the Anthony Nolan Register in the United Kingdom. This is not only costly and time consuming, but also offers little hope to many Australians of diverse ethnic background.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government therefore announced in the Budget that it would make $700,000 available to assist the establishment of Australia's own bone marrow registry, encouraged by the support that had been shown for the initiative at the June meeting of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council, AHMAC, as well as by the Australian community more generally.

The Australian register will be made up of computer registers of donors in each State and Territory. Where an initial search proves unsuccessful, a search of the national register will be undertaken. In addition, the national register will be the point of contact with international registers for international searches of the Australian register.

It is presently envisaged that the Red Cross will perform the required tissue typing for the registry, as well as entering records on the computer system, while the States are likely to have responsibility for the recruitment of potential donors. These issues of structure, required funding levels and management of the registry are to be considered by AHMAC at its October meeting.

I am hopeful that the Australian bone marrow register will begin to be operational by the end of this year. Within a few short years the registry should obtain a large pool of potential donors, making bone marrow transplantation between unrelated Australians a common occurrence. An effective register will not only reduce direct costs on the health care system, but ensure improved survival rates and quality of life for those Australians who are unfortunate enough to require a bone marrow transplant.

Can the Minister explain to the House what this regulation will be, whose regulations they will be and how the process will work? It is worth reminding the honourable member of it at this stage when he talks about what is necessary to deliver lower prices to people. He had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has received many representations on these reports and believes a statement is necessary to allay public concern. The Government is committed to maintaining the essential common carrier roles of Telecom and Australia Post. Telecom and Australia Post are great national institutions that will not be put at risk. Telecom will remain, as it has been, the national terrestrial common carrier in telecommunications.
He went on to say:

This is during the course of the campaign. He continued:

If it were not for the fact that Telecom unions were now clearly a Labor Party front, one would expect them to be honest about this and condemn this ALP position. So far as the Government is concerned, competition in the terminal market is an open question and the Government will consider this in the light of its further consideration of the recommendations of the Davidson Committee report.

It is one thing to change one's mind when one is in government: it is another thing to change one's mind when one is in opposition. Changing its mind on a few things is something which an intelligent government does when it has to work its way through proposals. Hairy-chested Opposition declarations are a different matter. When government was concerned, the Opposition had one very clear position on telecommunications. Now the question, as I recollect, on this matter--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the answer? Answer the question!
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!

—His question went to the issue of how the Government would be able to ensure, via regulation or a regulator or whatever, that there would be a capacity to deliver at declining prices. Let me tell him that, unless that is in place, the evidence from elsewhere is that either one of two events will occur: either prices will rise or no competition will take place.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a couple of systems internationally which are totally deregulated on the sort of contestability model that from time to time the Opposition has put out. They exist in Sweden and they exist in New Zealand. There is no regulator in either case, nor is there regulation, and in neither case is there competition. The simple fact is that barriers to entry in the telecommunications market, if one decides seriously for competition, have to be determined on the basis of government legging that into the system. Anyone who knows anything about telecommunications, as opposed to imposing some Chicago business school theory on it, knows that that is the case. There is essentially no argument within the Government on the fact that that ought to be done and no argument by anyone in telecommunications that that is the only way to go.

As far as a regulator is concerned, unless there is a regulator in place, as I said, there will be no competition. But the fact that we intend to maintain Telecom in full public ownership in the structure which it has effectively established to this point, with the profit stream that it has and the profit stream that OTC has, with the fact that there is room to manoeuvre within the structure of Telecom's current investment program in its own infrastructure, means that we are able to say with confidence that we can maintain the community service obligations (CSO) of Telecom and that we can maintain the rural program. The Opposition in its position cannot say that. It has not only proposed competition; it has proposed selling the monopoly.

Let me tell the House what happens when that occurs elsewhere. It is such a gigantic step to oblige the capital markets to absorb the real costs of a telephone monopoly-an asset worth something between $15 billion and $20 billion-that it becomes the Opposition's preoccupation. It was the preoccupation of the British Government; it was the preoccupation of the New Zealand Government; and, being the preoccupation of the British and New Zealand governments, they went through that process of introducing competition without focusing on the principal issue: competition.

When a government gets people to pay something like $15 billion or $20 billion, it does not rock around to those people and say, `And by the way, while we are getting you to pay $15 billion or $20 billion, we will be working pretty hard to make sure that you cannot get a return on your capital or a return that you would consider satisfactory.' That is the weakness in the Opposition's position when it goes out to members of the public and attempts to convince them that what it is going to do is to produce lower telephone prices for them, because it will not. There is no evidence from anywhere to suggest that it will, if that is the basis on which it intends to proceed.

The Opposition has, in a half-hearted and unsystematic way-which represents the total way that it has approached the question of its communications reform-given evidence of that. The fact that it has a weak, pathetic National Party as its operators now has to some extent excluded from the public the fact that that is so. The Opposition has said to them that they will shift the community service obligations on to the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Right up front on Budget.

—The honourable member has never served in a government. Let me tell him what the Budget process is like. Take an example where a government has $250m rocking around free and it is making a choice between knocking off community service obligations and, perhaps, increasing the price of prescriptions. The honourable member should see where he goes when he is putting up an argument on one of those choices. He might last with community service obligations for a year or two, but then it is out the window. ANSWER.PARA: On top of that, the Opposition has a $540m investment program proceeding in the bush, which is essential to ensure that people in the bush get an adequate service. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bass.

—When it comes down to determining the nature of competition, these issues are absolutely essential, and I will bet my bottom dollar that when Opposition members went round their party room looking at what they might do on the issue of competition, the Opposition spokesman did not run through these particular little problems for their benefit. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to implement real and substantial reform in telecommunications.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, last night the Government-after what seems like months and months of blood-letting and self-immolation- reached what it was pleased to call decisions in principle on the reform of telecommunications in Australia. It is fair to say, by way of compression, that there were three substantial elements in the proposal that was announced last night. The first is that there is to be a combination of Telecom Australia and OTC Ltd, making a megacom, as it has popularly been called. The second proposal, apparently, is that there is to be allowed in this country now, as a great leap forward in the cause of reform, one competitor additional to Telecom in the whole telecommunications area. The third proposal is consistent with the Australian Labor Party's attitude that it is all right to privatise bodies of this sort which are continually making losses. It is a proposal to sell Aussat Pty Ltd, our communications public company.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be said at the outset that the reality is a far cry from the description that has been given by the Government of these matters as being decisions in principle because the Australian people, having given consideration to them, could only conclude that if this was reform then it can only be described as a disaster and it can only be concluded that the Government has abandoned all serious attitudes towards bringing in substantial, real and effective reform in telecommunications.

It should be understood so that we can see where we have got so far as this Government is concerned, where this whole saga started. Of course, it started in the first flush of enthusiasm after the last election when the Government, through the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), announced that this was to be the final gloss put on the golden age of reform.

We were told in this letter that was conveniently leaked, a letter that was sent by the Prime Minister to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), that this final polish and gloss of substantial reform in a number of areas is now to be added to the history of the Hawke Government. The Prime Minister said in this letter:
. . . our fourth term offers opportunities and carries an obligation to quicken the pace of reform.

When we look at the decisions that were made and announced last night we cannot conclude other than that those hopes have been sadly disappointed and that the Government has abandoned any serious attempt to introduce substantial reform in telecommunications.

When we look at what has been proposed by the Government it must surely be conceded that at least two very substantial and fundamental defects are at the root of the Government's proposals. The first is that, as I have said already, one of the proposals is to combine Telecom and OTC. We are opposed to that. We think it is a backward step not only because OTC itself is opposed to it and will be dragged very reluctantly, kicking and protesting, to this forced marriage, but because one cannot conclude other than that the megacom proposal will increase government control over telecommunications in Australia and strengthen government control over the whole industry. If we are looking for freedom, the benefits that come from deregulation and real reform, this is the last step that should be taken-to strengthen government control over telecommunications or anything else-at a time when we want more private investment, more incentive and more productivity in this country. It is a very backward step indeed.

The second fundamental defect in what has been proposed is that the Government is to allow only one competitor. We and many informed commentators in this area say that that is no competition at all, that is not reform, that is not what was heralded by the Prime Minister in April this year in the letter that he sent to the Minister. To allow one competitor is not to introduce real reform and real competition in telecommunications or anything else.

It is not only the Opposition that has been promoting that view or pointing out that we will not make progress in this area if we establish a duopoly, as it is called, in place of the monopoly that we presently have. As I pointed out at Question Time, a very respected body, Austel, the Australian Telecommunications Authority, has looked at all the possible models for structuring competition in telecommunications. It looked at this matter specifically in the context of mobile telephones, but what it said applies to other areas, and was clearly intended to do so. In making a sustained economic examination of this area, Austel said that one will achieve nothing by simply putting a duopoly in place instead of the monopoly that one has at the moment. Austel said that that is not reform, it will not introduce competition and it will not give the benefits of competition; it said that if we want real benefits of competition we must go further than simply this one approved single competitor allowed by the Government.

At Question Time we were told by the Minister that not enough people are making a serious and sustained examination of the detailed issues of this matter. It is worthwhile reflecting that Austel has done it, and this is what Austel said about the duopoly which the present Government is now proposing:

Because it is relatively easy under a duopoly to match quickly any new competitive initiative taken by a rival, ``live and let live'' attitudes can easily develop such that competition is far more apparent than real and the outcome is little different from that of a monopoly.

Austel goes on to say that monopoly prices could be charged, no real choice might be offered to the consumer and there could be little incentive for adopting new technologies and minimising costs generally. After a sustained and detailed examination of the economic case for exactly the proposal that the present Government has put forward, Austel concludes that it will get the Government nothing by way of benefits and indeed it will be a retrograde step because we will have price fixing, monopoly prices, very limited real choice and very little improvement for the consumer.

Austel then goes on to look at the other side of the argument and makes out a sustained case for allowing more competition. It says that indeed we will get benefits in prices and in consumer service if we have more than one competitor, if we have a greater competitive structure set up. It says that greater net benefits in terms of overall efficiency and competition in all aspects of the price product service package are potentially achievable under conditions of-as it describes it-oligopoly; that is, of more competitors than there are under a duopoly.

Austel quite rightly puts the spotlight on those three important aspects-price, product and service. It is saying exactly what the Opposition has maintained through the whole of this debate-that if we want improvements in terms of prices, the product that will be delivered and the service which is to be given to the consumer, then we will not achieve benefits in those areas by simply allowing one government approved competitor to Telecom, but that we must have open competition.

That is a sustained case in support of open competition. It is a sustained case which the Government has clearly overlooked in coming to the conclusions that it has on this matter. As I have said, it is not simply the case that we have put. From the very day the Industry Commission was established, the Government has placed great reliance on that body. As we heard in Question Time, the Chairman of that body said recently in a speech-how prophetic it was when one looks at these comments-that in the year when we finally dismantled the domestic two-airline agreement and all the inefficiencies that it delivered, it would be ironic if we were to plunge ourselves into another closed system of regulated duopoly in telecommunications. That is what has happened. Ironic it may be or not, but the reality is plain for us all to see now-the Government has plunged this country into yet another closed system of regulated duopoly, this time in telecommunications.

We saw an additional gloss in Question Time. We had, as I understood it, the concession from the Minister that the proposal put by the Government yesterday will not reduce prices of telephone services but rather that those reductions in prices, if they do come, will come only from more regulation. At the end of the day that seems to be at the bottom of exactly what is now being proposed by the Government-more regulation instead of less. That is what the Government has given us. That is the big disappointment. That is the failure of the Hawke Government in this area of so-called reform. The Government stands condemned for abandoning the one prospect that it had of introducing real competition and getting for the consumers and industry in this country the benefits of true competition. It has abandoned that chance and it was its last opportunity.

As we said last time this matter was put before the Parliament, there is an alternative plan, one which we believe will give industry and consumers very considerable benefits from the policy that we have promoted. It is, as I have said, one which is now supported by Austel itself because it has made out a very strong economic case for the advantages of open competition. We have said that that must be at the top of the list of priorities. The essential ingredient must be competition. We have committed ourselves to full and effective competition in all sectors of telecommunications. It is only when we commit ourselves to that competition that we will get the benefits that telecommunications, properly managed, can give to the Australian people.

Secondly, we say that not only must there be competition in all areas of telecommunications but also there must be competition in network facilities. It is essential-the Government now seems to be alert to the importance of this-that if we are going to have an effective system of competition then the competitors must have access to the network. In our private members' Bill that has been introduced into the Parliament we have proposed a sensible mechanism for allowing that connection to take place. In that Bill we have made it perfectly plain, as I hope I have again today, that we will achieve nothing by combining Telecom and OTC, other than increasing the stranglehold of government on telecommunications at the very time when we want and need less government control.

We have said in addition to that that there are a number of specific proposals which have to be addressed and which the Opposition has made a sensible decision on. In the first place they are the proposals with respect to mobile telephones. The Government has now had the Austel report for months. The trouble is that the logical consequences of having these concepts floating free without any sensible policy conclusion is that in the end one has no policy at all-and in fact the Opposition has no policy at all.

As a priority, the Committee wished to address the difficult and sensitive issue of illegal entrants, given the impending end of the limited concessionary arrangements on 1 June 1990 and 30 June 1990, which required them, firstly, to leave Australia, thereby not incurring any time penalty should they wish to re-apply immediately for entry to Australia; or, secondly, to apply to regularise their status on spouse or economic grounds.

This deadline was perceived by the Committee to create serious problems of implementation for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs of any recommendations requiring amendment and of potential injustice to those affected. Hence, once the Committee decided to inquire into matters affecting illegals, it considered that it would be unfair if some people were required to leave after 30 June and before the Committee had an opportunity to report to the Parliament. As Chairman of the Committee, I therefore wrote to the Minister on 20 June 1990 arguing that, while not wishing to encourage illegals currently here to remain, the Committee was seeking further evidence in respect of these matters and therefore requested an extension of time beyond the current 1 June and 30 June dates until 30 September 1990 for the concessional arrangements now applicable, and for the voluntary departure without the re-entry restriction.

The Minister agreed to extend the concessionary period until 31 October 1990, but emphasised that this would be the final deadline. The Committee further determined that, in order to give the Minister and Cabinet adequate time to consider the report and draft any necessary legislative amendments, it would report as soon as possible in September. This extremely tight reporting deadline imposed severe constraints on the Committee, its secretariat and its adviser. The Committee is of the view that if it is to meet time constraints in the future, deadlines may need to be more reasonable and will require a hefty increase in the resources of the Committee.

Much interest has been generated in the report. To date, over 90 submissions have been received. The Committee also held public hearings in Melbourne, Canberra and Sydney consulting with a large number of community groups, as well as the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

I must take the opportunity to point out the severe practical difficulties that the complexity of the regulations has caused to many people. It was a common complaint raised in submissions and at the public hearings. The issue has also been raised by Mr Justice Wilcox in a recent Federal Court case when he stated:
The task of ascertaining the position in relation to a particular applicant or a particular type of visa or entry permit is akin to feeling one's way through a labyrinth.

I and my fellow Committee members can only concur with that sentiment. However, we recognise that a revised and simplified version of the regulations has been promised by the Minister. The Committee regards that exercise as having a high priority.

I now turn to the report. Australia's migration laws have been developed to control the entry and stay of non-citizens in Australia. There is, therefore, a need to maintain the Government's migration program within pre-determined levels and to enable the removal of persons who are either in Australia illegally or whose presence in Australia is not in the best interests of the Australian community. However, there is also a need to consider some of the cases of those people who were here illegally prior to 19 December 1989 when the law changed so dramatically, and where it can be shown that their cases merit consideration.

The Committee does not condone or encourage illegality as a back door to permanent entry to Australia. It supports the efforts of the Government and the Department to, firstly, minimise current levels of illegal entry and, secondly, prevent a future problem. However, the Committee is unaware of any other developed country which has automatic and mandatory deportation for nearly all of its illegals, as is the case under the tough provisions of the new model.

In these circumstances, the Committee believes that some limited opportunity should be made available for a small proportion of the total number of illegals to regularise their status. The people we are concerned about are some of the people who may be innocently illegal-those who have a compelling compassionate case or those who have been absorbed into Australian society for at least five years and who can show that they have made a substantial contribution to Australia. Such a limited window of opportunity will encourage people to come forward before 31 October and will help to minimise the extent of the illegal `twilight society'.

The Committee is further concerned that the Government's intention that illegal entrants should come forward before 31 October 1990 will not be fulfilled unless the new control model is tempered with discretion and compassion. The Committee believes that the main way of dealing with the problems of long term illegal immigrants, generally, is by empowering the Immigration Review Tribunal to consider applications from illegal immigrants who come forward or who are apprehended before 31 October 1990. This Tribunal would be empowered, in the case of innocent illegals, to make recommendations to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and, in all other cases, to make a determination. A special category of people which the Committee is particularly concerned about is those people who are now illegal or who, in the future, may become illegal through no fault of their own. The Committee is unanimous in its concern about this particular category of people-the innocent illegals.

It is important to note that people can become illegal even if they are honest in their dealings with immigration staff, have no knowledge of the illegality or have no intention of becoming an illegal. Certain children born or residing in Australia fall into this category. The Committee argues that innocent illegals, here illegally through no fault of their own, should have the opportunity to regularise their status.

All members of the Committee, with the exception of Senator McKiernan, are of the view that the Immigration Review Tribunal should consider the cases of the innocent illegals and other cases of compassion. We thus strongly recommend the expanded role of the Tribunal. In general, the Committee resolved that an illegal immigrant would be able to apply to the tribunal provided that he or she has been:
in Australia for at least five years prior to 31 October 1990 (that is arrived in Australia prior to 31 October 1985) and is able to present evidence demonstrating this fact; and
has come forward and presented themselves to the Registrar of the Immigration Tribunal before 31 October 1990 by either:
(i) completing an application form as outlined below; or
(ii) completing a notice of intent to lodge such an application in which they undertake to complete a full application form by the 15th December 1990; and
(iii) completes such application form by 15 December;

is able to present information and evidence which would satisfy the Tribunal that they have made a positive and substantial contribution to Australia during the period in which they had been in Australia; or

can demonstrate that there are compelling or compassionate circumstances which contributed to the applicant's illegal standing and which should be taken into account by the Tribunal as reasons for granting stay in Australia.
In making its determination, the Tribunal will take note of the following relevant circumstances in the case of those applying under paragraph 32.2(b):
age;
length of residence in Australia;
strength of connections with Australia;
personal history, including character, conduct and employment record;
domestic circumstances;
compassionate circumstances;
any representation received on the person's behalf.

In rare cases where there are compelling and compassionate circumstances and where persons have been in Australia less than five years or were prevented by serious intervening circumstances from making an application before 31 October 1990, such persons may seek leave of the Registrar of the Tribunal to lodge an application for the Tribunal's consideration. This clause is to be used only in rare cases.

A further issue of concern to the Committee which particularly affects innocent illegals is the requirement in regulation 42 that, where an applicant for an entry permit is illegal, the application has to be lodged not more than 12 months after the person became illegal.

Innocent illegals are predominantly children and/or those who are unaware they are illegal. The illegality may not be discovered until many years after the time when the person became illegal, yet he or she will be caught by Regulation 42, no matter what their circumstances may be. The Committee has recommended in chapter 5 of its report that provision for a waiver of the time period for lodgment of an application in appropriate circumstances be incorporated in the regulations.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Committee in recommending its general approach is in no way trying to undermine or prejudice the Government's program of control of illegals. On the contrary, it is concerned that the Government's intentions `will not be fulfilled unless the control model is tempered with discretion and compassion'. The five-year qualifying period for applications has been strongly supported by the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils at its recent national conference and by many ethnic community representatives.

On pages 73 and 74 of the report, we outline our assessment of the total number likely to be allowed to remain in Australia as a result of this process. Of the 90,000 illegal entrants, between 3,000 and 4,000 are likely to be able to stay. This is not a large number in the total illegal population but it will deal with the most deserving cases. I reject the argument that this concession will establish a precedent and that people will be encouraged to hide away for five years and then come forward, hoping to take advantage of the scheme. This is a complete misrepresentation of the intentions of the Committee and the nature of the scheme. This will be a one-off scheme and not ongoing. The cut-off point of 31 October 1985 is intended to be absolute and not a movable feast.

If the Government is serious about enforcing the 31 October deadline, it must publicise the fact that people must come forward by that date, otherwise they will suffer penalties and certainly will receive no further concessions of this nature. Indeed, it is because of the severity of the scheme after 31 October 1990 that the Committee has decided that this one-off concession should be made.
Mr Deputy Speaker, there are many other matters and recommendations in the report which we urge all honourable members to consider and we urge the Government to adopt.

Finally, I should like to thank my fellow Committee members for their time and efforts in getting this first report to Parliament. I should also like to express the Committee's gratitude to Dr Kathryn Cronin, the legal consultant to the Committee. Dr Cronin's dedication, professionalism and expertise are highly valued by the Committee. I should also like to thank the staff of the secretariat, Robina Mills and Heidi Quinlan, for the enormous work which they put in during the last few weeks in getting this report together for honourable members. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak and respond to this, the first report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, entitled Illegal Entrants in Australia-Balancing Control and Compassion. There is one thing with which I agree with the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who spoke on behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, and that is that balancing control and compassion is a difficult exercise. It is a matter which members of the Committee grappled with over some months. I would encourage those who are interested in this matter to read the report and also to read the dissenting reports because what becomes apparent is that balancing control and compassion is a matter on which there are numbers of different views.

SPEECH.PARA: There are in this case, Mr Deputy Speaker, the views of the majority that comprised four members of the Committee of 10. The report shows that one member of the Committee was unable to attend meetings of the Committee and took no part in its deliberations, and he regretted that that was the case.

Thereafter, there are dissenting reports by me and Senator Olsen. Senator McKiernan dissented, Senator Cooney dissented and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) dissented. We dissented, I might say, in different ways and on different aspects of the report. But it is significant that in reading this report the view of the majority clearly lacks authority. It is not a report that ought to persuade the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand).

There are aspects about which I should like to simply reinforce strongly the view of the Committee and the honourable member who spoke before me. In relation to the question of the framework of law in which this question of illegal immigration is addressed, it is clear that the law is so complex that a judge described it as feeling one's way through a labyrinth. I would further quote the judge where he had this to say:

As will already be apparent, understanding the regulations is no easy matter. Apart from the initial problem of obtaining an up-to-date text of the regulations, the reader is confronted with a lengthy and complex document, abounding with cross-references, from one provision to another.

It was because of those comments that the judge went on to make the observation that he did. The honourable member for Calwell draws certain conclusions from that. I draw different conclusions. The conclusion I draw is that the way in which this law was implemented last year was fundamentally flawed. Mistakes were made but they were mistakes of the Government's own making. They were not the mistakes of the Opposition. They were not the mistakes of the Australian Democrats. They were mistakes of the Government.

The former Minister described the decision-making process as one of trial and error. I thought that was a remarkable statement. I made the observation in relation to that that I thought it was far more error than trial. The fact is that the law is flawed. The law was not brought forward with a proper consideration of matters of compassion nor were the issues of control properly balanced. Members of the Committee saw fit to seek an extension of time to enable consideration of this matter. The Committee, as is clear, has worked under a very considerable difficulty because the time was not there for it to come to considered conclusions on which all members could agree. But the timing was a matter upon which the Government took advice from the Committee. It was not timing which I supported, as honourable members will know. The minutes show that I dissented in relation to that matter; it was not a unanimous decision of the Committee. I had a concern at that time that we would be giving mixed messages in relation to the Government's resolve to deal with the question of illegal immigration were we to add further to the time in which people might consider their positions under the framework of law introduced by this Government.

The honourable member who spoke before me, the honourable member for Calwell, indicated that this was a significant problem, but the report, in my view, still-as the Government does-gives estimates which largely understate the enormity of it. The Government now admits that 90,000 illegals exist. Until the Committee started its work the Government persisted with the view that there were merely 60,000 illegals in Australia. That figure came about as a result of our deliberations and pressing for information. To that number of 90,000 should be added the 30,000 applicants for grant of residence status who are in the pipeline for processing and whose circumstances are presently being considered. It may well be that a majority of them will have to leave, but certainly a majority of those are illegal. They are made valid only because they have been permitted to be processed.

To that should be added the 20,000 People's Republic of China (PRC) nationals granted temporary residency. Most of those have not been included in illegal calculations to date, yet clearly, as was shown by the information made available by the Government, many of them even at the time of Tiananmen Square were then illegal. Nor has the Government added most of the 25,000 PRC students who arrived post Tiananmen Square and are now in breach of these conditions. As most of those arrived more than six months ago on six-month visas, I would have to say that the majority, no doubt, are now illegal. I suggest that the total figure is closer to 150,000. That is the size and nature of the problem that we have to address. The numbers are greater than the total migration program for this country.

Lack of resolve in dealing with this issue is the most significant factor contributing to the growth of illegal entry. Mixed signals which have been given by the Government over time-and I have to say extensions of time constitute such mixed signals-are an invitation to those who want to come here and find that under our framework of law they are excluded. All of this has been compounded by the flawed and poorly drafted delegated legislation. Each attempt to address the difficulties has led to a postponement of compliance activities and it has held out the prospect of regularisation of status to illegals within Australia whether or not this was the case or the intention of the Government.

I have to say that further significant steps to expand the circumstances in which claims to remain here in Australia may be advanced will only further serve to undermine the Government's compliance efforts. In coming to a view as to what the balance should be, the majority of Committee members in this case have come to a view that the range of circumstances which might be considered should be further widened. I have to say, first, that the scheme, when reduced to its simplest elements, accommodates the applications of innocent illegals at any time. I have to say I think that cases of innocent illegals ought to be capable of being addressed. Secondly, the scheme accommodates those with compelling and compassionate claims. They can also be made at any time. I have to say in relation to those matters that I think the test ought to be stronger than just compelling and compassionate claims, and I come to that view in my minority report.

It provides further that those who apply before 31 October 1990 shall have an entitlement if they have been here five years or more to stay on permanently on what are called absorption grounds. Honourable members may be interested to know how many people that affects, how many people would have an entitlement to lodge an application. On page 20 of the report it indicates that of the 60,000 people that the Government previously thought to be in Australia illegally-and the Committee was advised of this on 7= June-more than 10,159 people are so affected. The honourable member who spoke before me endeavoured to rationalise that figure down, but that is the number who would be entitled to lodge applications. If that does not send a signal, I do not know what would.

I have to say that I believe that the scheme proposed by my colleagues is defective in three important respects. First, it is unduly complex and difficult to follow. Secondly, it tends to confirm in the minds of prospective illegals that simply by staying on in Australia eventually governments will relent and permanent residency will be possible. Further, where breaches of our law are concerned, it rewards them. We know that most illegals in Australia obtain employment in breach of section 83 of the Act and the absorption test proposed by the majority involves looking at those people who have worked here illegally and, if they have paid taxes, rewarding them for it.

There are really only two matters that need to be dealt with. The first is that of innocent illegals, as identified by the Committee in chapter three of the report. Secondly, in the most compelling, compassionate and deserving cases-where, in my view, it would be unconscionable to require a person in Australia temporarily or illegally to leave- some limited, residual discretion should exist to enable claims to be made and processed. It is in those very limited, compelling, tragic and compassionate circumstances that I suggest that the Tribunal set up by the Government should be in a position, where circumstances are drawn to its attention, to recommend to the Minister-not to determine the matter; not to take the matter out of the hands of the Government- that he look at the situation.

In reaching its decision, the Tribunal would have to have regard to these factors: the public interest, which would normally suggest that deportation would be a proper course; that the circumstances that are to be considered would most likely have arisen since the person arrived in Australia; that the strength of connections with Australia which would result in further residency being continued were sufficiently substantial that it would be a preferable result to deportation.

In my view, absorption of less than nine years certainly would not be seen as a factor on its own that would warrant any consideration by the Tribunal in making its recommendation. It is recognised in the table to which I referred that some 874 people have been in the country illegally for nine years or more. I have suggested further qualifications to that matter so that the Minister may ensure that it does not become one where control of the program is lost.

I think it is important to note in relation to those matters recommended by me that my colleague the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who has put in a separate dissenting report, picks up many of those recommendations that I have made. I think it is important to note that my colleague Senator McKiernan, who is a Government member, makes it very clear that, while he condones the Minister's having some responsibility in looking at innocent illegals, he is also very worried about the prospect of watering down and backing away from announced enforcement policies of the Government yet again. He would see that as being a sign of weakness by his own Government, were it to succumb on this matter. Senator Cooney goes on to say:
I am unable to endorse the majority report. I give my reasons.
He says further:

That balance is to be struck in circumstances where there is room only for a small proportion of the thousands upon thousands of people who want to settle here. The acceptance as a permanent resident of someone who until then has been present illegally means the denial of entry to another who has obeyed the law in seeking entry to Australia. That poses an issue of equity.
He goes on to make the point that he does not believe that these matters have been properly and fairly determined by the elaborate process suggested by the majority of members.

I hope that the Minister will take on board the view of the majority who dissented. It is put in different ways but the report is clearly in conflict with the view of the majority, in this instance a majority of four. It is a matter of balancing control and compassion. If the proposal of the majority is accepted it will balance compassion so far, in my view, as to outweigh the proper control that the immigration program of this country requires.
