SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with considerable pleasure that I speak in support of this report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, Illegal Entrants in Australia-Balancing control and compassion, because it is the first that I have been involved with that has been presented to this House. I have long had an interest in migration, being a migrant myself. Whichever way one does it, migration is disruptive. As a nation chiefly of migrants and their descendants we should all be aware of this. For those who are not, I commend the very fine Australian play Their Country's Good on the formation of the Australian nation by involuntary migrants.

SPEECH.PARA: Some migrants come here illegally for reasons which vary as widely as they do themselves and at the start of this inquiry into their status I was strongly of the view that they should all be deported pretty well compulsorily without appeal and on detection. My reasoning was that this country has and needs a robust and orderly immigration program. If our electorates believe the program not to be within the Government's control they will withdraw public support for that program and, if the 90 per cent of the applicants for migration who are rejected believe that illegal entry can succeed, they will be tempted to take that route.

Illegal entrants, then, are an affront and a threat to the migration policy as a whole and to its orderly character in particular. I supported very tough actions against illegals and opposed in particular the repetition of the amnesties which were granted over a decade ago. As a result, the extremely tough proposals introduced in the legislation of last year seemed to me to be appropriate except for the abolition of ministerial discretion. I was and remain of the view that the total codification of the migration regulations was not appropriate. That was undertaken before I was in this House; so I accept its introduction and will try to make it work as best I can.

During our series of public hearings, which, as the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) pointed out, were very extensive, my views on the situation of illegal entrants shifted somewhat. Crucial in this transition of my point of view were the so-called innocent illegals to which both the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), and the honourable member for Calwell have referred. Broadly speaking, these are people who have unknowingly acquired an illegal entrant status. We had a large number of examples of such circumstances presented to us. The ones I draw to the House's attention are those who have become unknowingly and unwittingly illegal because they entered as children and were in no position to discover it at that time-and some only find out when they apply for a passport-or women who, for whatever reason, have allowed their husbands to undertake the business of applying for migration to this country, for permanent resident status, and then discover that it was done badly in some way or another and they have acquired illegal entrant status unknowingly, unwittingly and unintentionally.

I believe it was the consensus of the Committee that there are people who would be unwarrantedly harshly treated by the regime that it was proposed be introduced at the end of October. I concede that I started to look at other instances rather more sympathetically but always tried to do so against the background of the need to maintain the integrity of the immigration program and system as a whole.

As the previous speaker pointed out, there are probably between 100,000 and 150,000 illegal entrants in Australia. If the proposed new regime is introduced on 1 November, a date which has already been postponed on a number of occasions, they will all be subject to mandatory deportation on detection. Until that date some relatively minor concessions already apply. I do not relish the prospect of the numerous deportations which will ensue from the extended personnel and financial resources which are to be deployed to enforce the new regime but I accept the necessity of doing this at a time of a growing problem of illegal entrance globally-and we are not the only country faced with it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Canada.

—The honourable member mentions Canada. Canada, a similar country to our own, was investigated quite thoroughly and the honourable member is quite right in saying that Canada has acquired an illegal entrance problem of disturbing proportions. We have that problem to a much lesser extent. As a result I accept the harshness of the regime we intended to introduce in November as a firm but fair policy. A firm but fair policy is a decent policy; a harsh and unfair one is not. The bordering line is often difficult to determine.

SPEECH.PARA: The majority of the Committee-and it was a majority voting at the time of the vote being taken-proposes in its report that innocent illegals be given particular appeal rights to regularise their status via a tribunal to the Minister, and be allowed to do it before and after 1 November. It also proposes that the same tribunal be able to receive before 31 October applications from other illegal entrants to regularise their status but to do so in accord with pretty strict qualifications. These concern compelling and compassionate circumstances, their own personal behaviour while they have been here-and, indeed, before they came here-the length of stay that they have had in Australia, and the circumstances of that stay. This would establish their ability to apply to the tribunal. These applicants would then be assessed on further criteria the nature of which assessment is essentially to determine whether their continued stay would serve the interests of the Australian community as a whole.

The previous speaker talked about the number of persons that would be involved in this process and in the report we have estimated the figure to be of the order of 4,000. It is difficult to be any more precise than that because innocent illegals may not even know at the present time that they are illegal. The number of people who would qualify to apply cannot be accurately determined at this time but to the best of our knowledge 4,000 would be a reasonable figure to anticipate. Our advisers have suggested that even this is larger than would be the case and that 1,000 might be closer to the mark.

After the end of October the new, very severe regime could then proceed in its firm posture, having, via the system, offered the opportunity for the most compelling of illegal cases, including people who are innocently illegal and do not know they are in that situation, to regularise their status. The regime we propose then becomes firm but fair. Some of the Committee felt that this was too compassionate an approach and placed a greater emphasis on the need to maintain the total integrity of the immigration program as a whole. They wanted toughness maintained and would make the exception, in the case put by one honourable senator, only in the case of innocent illegals. I doubt, however, that they perceive the community reaction which is likely to be engendered by undue harshness in the future.

Other Committee members, including the honourable member for Dundas, who spoke before me in this debate, accepted the tribunal but wanted different rules embodied. This may be an understandable position but its likely effect is to reduce the acceptability of the report by preventing a bipartisan consensus emerging. As a result the report is less likely to be implemented as a whole. This may well be their intention. Others again-outside the Committee but in public testimony-went much further, arguing for concessions including such things as amnesties which I believe would pose unacceptable threats to the integrity of the immigration program as a whole. I commend the report, with its appropriate balance, as its title suggests, of control and compassion, to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not, I hasten to point out, a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. I have not had the opportunity to read the report, which has only just been tabled. Perhaps I am rushing in where angels ought not rush. However, it is a matter that I am very concerned about.
—Where angels fear to tread.

—My colleague reminds me that the expression is `where angels fear to tread'. It may be there that I am rushing. Nevertheless I, and, I think, many Australians, are justifiably concerned about the extent of illegal immigration into this country. I notice that the title of the report deals with the question of balancing control and compassion. I personally-and I feel that I would be speaking for many Australians-would want to come down strongly on the side of control and detection. It is the matter of detection that I want to deal with briefly this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very pleased to hear my colleague the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), a member of the Committee, say that there was considerable dissent in respect of the Committee report. As I listened to the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) I became increasingly concerned about whether what he was saying was a view or position shared by many people other than himself. As it turns out it is now clear to me that there is considerable dissent in respect of this particular report. I found it rather quaint that we should talk of innocent illegals. It seems to be something of a contradiction in terms.

Let me talk about the question of detention. We all recognise-it appears that the Committee has recognised it-that the problem of illegal immigration is endemic in Australia. Whether we are talking about 90,000 or 150,000 people who are here illegally, it is a matter of some concern. Of particular concern to me is the number of those people who are entering on tourist visas and who are actually working in Australia. I believe that that is a matter that ought to concern a lot of people. If we are talking about 100,000 people who are in Australia illegally, there is a distinct possibility that a substantial proportion of those may actually be working here. If they are working here they are presumably doing work that could be done by people who are here legally or who are already Australian citizens. In other words, these illegals are replacing as many as 150,000 people in the Australian work force.

Furthermore, we ought to be concerned that perhaps those 150,000 people who are here illegally are probably not paying taxes. Therefore, I hope that the Committee has come down strongly on the side of control in respect of this particular problem. I would like to suggest to the Committee-perhaps it is a bit late to ask it to consider these matters but I want to raise them and put them on the record-some practical ways in which this problem of detection can be addressed. It is not enough to have a few officers running around trying to find these illegal immigrants because the problem is so obviously out of control that we would have to have an enormous police force to do that.

I want to make three suggestions as to how, if we are serious about this problem, we can address it on a fairly simple administrative level. The first proposition is that we can deny illegal immigrants access to a tax file number. Secondly, we can redesign or restructure Commonwealth Employment Service procedures to ensure that those who are using those facilities are bona fide residents or citizens. Thirdly, we can ensure that drivers licences, which are by their very nature a de facto ID card, are issued only to legal residents or Australian citizens. In respect of the tax file number it is quite clear that, with no access to a tax file number, de facto ID or drivers licence and no ability to gain access to unemployment benefits, illegal residency in Australia will be very much less attractive to these people than it apparently is at the moment. In fact, they may find life here rather difficult if they are unable to work here.

A by-product and another concern regarding the tightening up of administrative procedures in respect of these matters is that these people would also have greater difficulty in gaining credit. This is another thing that they can do quite readily. That also creates a problem for people who give credit to them by virtue of the fact that they front up with a drivers licence which they can gain very readily. I suppose at worst-I say at worst because it is a worst option-if we were serious about this problem we may gain extra tax revenue because people working illegally without a tax file number will be taxed at the highest level, and I assume that they will not come forward to claim a tax refund. At least at worst there are some benefits in that particular situation.

I refer briefly to the application for a tax file number. It has some serious deficiencies. Firstly, the documents that one is asked to present when one applies for a tax file number are not difficult to procure. One has to present two category A documents. It is not difficult, if one reads the application form, to find that one has only to find a degree, a school examination certificate or a school examination report and combine that with a document such as a registered mortgage, title or deeds to real estate. Quite simply, on an administrative level the tightening up of that particular application form will in part address this particular problem.

The other glaring weakness that exists in respect of this application is that there is no requirement for photographic evidence. Surely, it is not too difficult to expect people applying for a tax file number to produce a photograph of themselves. If they were to do so, that would address some of the concerns that I have raised.

As far as the procedures of the Commonwealth Employment Service are concerned, it is fairly apparent that it has no concern with this problem. Perhaps it is not necessarily its responsibility. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it has only to ask three questions of people who come before it to play a part in addressing this problem. Firstly, `Were you born in Australia?'. Secondly, `If not, can you produce evidence that you are a legal resident or that you have actually achieved Australian citizenship?'. Thirdly, 'Are you allowed to work in Australia?'. It could ask people who answer that question affirmatively to produce evidence that they are allowed, within the terms of their visas, to work in Australia. The same sorts of questions ought to be asked in respect of people applying for drivers licences.

The criticism may well be levelled that all this adds to the administrative burdens in these particular areas. I believe that the problem is of such magnitude and concern to most Australians that if we are serious about solving this problem we should take up some of the suggestions that I have made and see whether we can go about reducing illegal immigration in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While there are many things I could say about this report, I appreciate the fact that agreements have been made about speakers lists and the business of the day, and I do not want to upset them any further. However, for quite some time I was Deputy Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations and, in view of some of the things that have been said in the debate, I want to make a couple of quick remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: One must be extremely careful when talking about compassion and amnesties for illegal immigrants. There are very occasional circumstances where somebody is genuinely what one could call an innocent illegal. In my 16 years in Parliament I have had a very close involvement with many difficult immigration cases and I think these occasional cases readily identify themselves. When one makes a full investigation of all the circumstances of cases where people claim that they genuinely believed they had the right sort of visa to come here as migrants, or that they had really given the right information, one finds that genuine circumstances do reveal themselves.

One of our difficulties at the moment is that, under the new regime, the migration law is extremely complex and very difficult to follow because of these regulations that we now have. Therefore, it is just that little bit more possible to be genuinely an innocent illegal. This is not quite the contradiction in terms that it sounds.

However, I am strongly at variance with the comments of the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley), who said that we need a more compassionate approach to illegals. One should be extremely cautious of the word `compassion' in the immigration debate. When I was on the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, I was one of the members who pushed very strongly for the compassionate factor in consideration of migration applications in those cases where there was a real compassion factor. We were successful in getting a small move in the regulations which does allow consideration, under very stringent conditions, of strong compassionate circumstances for those applying for migration. This is not the same thing as applying those conditions to somebody who comes here on a visitor's visa of some sort and then applies for a change of status.

It is very easy to mount what one can loosely call a case for compassion. If it can be mounted, usually it can be mounted before the person comes here. It should not be left until that person is here so that he or she can then play on the heartstrings-usually of the general Australian public-via the mass media of newspapers and certain television programs which conveniently give a very one-eyed story just for the sake of today's newspaper or today's program. Therefore, whilst it may be appropriate in the normal course of immigration to have the compassionate let out, basically it is not appropriate for illegals.

I have had many involvements with people who were under deportation orders who wanted some help, and I have to say I have encountered very few genuine cases. Marginal cases-and some very sad cases can arise here-usually involve people having come here on some sort of visa, decided they really like the place and stayed. They would have made good migrants had they applied in the normal way. When they are detected several years later, they have homes they have to sell and all sorts of other problems from which they have to extricate themselves. They have to get out of the country and cannot apply to come back for years. When you say to them, `For heaven's sake, why did you not apply to migrate and do it the right way?', they reply that they had heard there was to be an amnesty. If there is one way to ask for a disaster in an immigration program it is to let people think there will be amnesties. The statement that was put out on the last amnesty, jointly by the then Minister for immigration and the shadow Minister for immigration, stated that it was to be the last. If we are ever to have proper control over our immigration program, we have to stick with that statement made several years ago and have no more amnesties in this country; otherwise we will just end up with a shambles.

I have had numerous experiences, as I am sure have other members, of people who have become unfortunate illegals-unfortunate in the sense that they could have mounted a compassionate case. But they knew that they were illegal and that they could have come here in the right way and not caused heartache to other people. Nevertheless, they thought that somebody was going to be soft on them some time in the future.

I support what the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) says, that we need that small window for cases where there has been inadvertence, for example where somebody has misunderstood the directions that have been given by one of our posts overseas or something like that. But compassion is generally not the right word to use in such cases. Furthermore, we must never again have an immigration amnesty.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received the following message from the Senate:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Senate requests the House of Representatives to resume consideration of the Bill entitled a Bill for an Act to Establish an End of War List for Australian Service Personnel, which was transmitted to the House of Representatives for its concurrence on 2 November 1989 during the last session of the Parliament.
The message I have just reported raises a fundamental issue of parliamentary procedure which I must bring to the attention of the House.

By a message dated 2 November 1989 the Senate transmitted for the concurrence of the House the End of War List Bill 1989. On 21 November 1989 the message was reported to the House by the Chair, the Bill was read a first time and a motion for the second reading was moved by the present Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer). Debate on the motion was then adjourned. The Bill, together with all other outstanding business of the House, lapsed with the dissolution of the Houses on 19 February 1990 prior to the general election for the House of Representatives and the half Senate election which was held on 24 March 1990. The simple position, therefore, is that neither the End of War List Bill 1989 nor any other Bill on the Notice Paper at the time of dissolution on 19 February is now an item of business before the House of Representatives in the Thirty-sixth Parliament.

The message which the Senate has now sent asks the House to resume consideration of the lapsed Bill which was transmitted to the House, in the words of the Senate message, 'during the last session of the Parliament'. I highlight the words 'during the last session of the Parliament' because the Bill was not transmitted during the last session of this Parliament but during the session of the last Parliament.

The action by the Senate has been taken despite the provisions of Senate standing order 136, to which the House of Representatives standing order 264 is similar, which effectively forbids consideration of a Bill being resumed following a general election or a periodical election for the Senate. I should point out that the Senate suspended its Standing Orders to validate the action it has taken-that is, to enable the message to be sent to the House requesting that we resume consideration of the Bill.

Although it is unusual for a Speaker to question the actions of the Senate, I feel that on this occasion I should do so on the ground that the Senate has involved the House of Representatives by its actions. First, it may be argued that suspension of Standing Orders to enable this particular action of the Senate, while of undoubted validity, ignores proper parliamentary practice.

Secondly, those who drew up our Standing Orders included a provision for a Bill which lapsed at the prorogation of the session to be restored to the Notice Paper under certain conditions but they specifically excluded such action if an election intervened, as I mentioned earlier. The word `prorogation' as used in the Standing Orders should be read as `dissolution' in this particular circumstance, as a practice of having a prorogation prior to a dissolution is no longer followed and so, these days, the business of the House lapses at the end of a parliament, because of dissolution rather than prorogation.

The reason behind the prohibition in the standing order is that a new House should not be bound by the actions of its predecessor in so far as unfinished business is concerned because there is a new membership in the House-and indeed a new Ministry. In fact, the last election saw the return of 33 new members to this House, almost a quarter of the whole membership of the House. It should also be noted that the Senate also has a new membership which has not considered the Bill.

In raising this matter I emphasise that I am not expressing a view on the substance of the Bill itself. My comments are confined entirely to the question of the procedures of the House of Representatives and I have an obligation to advise the House of these matters.

The fact is that the Bill is not before the House and the message which I have just reported does not transmit the Bill to the House. If the Senate desires the House to consider the Bill, it needs to find a mechanism to bring it before the House which is not contrary to the provisions of House of Representatives standing order 264 and proper parliamentary procedure.

Accordingly it is suggested that, if the Senate desires to revive the Bill, it should introduce the Bill again and transmit it to the House for concurrence in accordance with normal procedures. To this end I would ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Free) to move a motion rejecting the Senate request.
Ordered that the message be taken into consideration forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Free) proposed:

That the House of Representatives, having considered Senate message number 48 requesting the House to resume consideration of the Bill entitled a Bill for an Act to Establish an End of War List for Australian Service Personnel, resolves that a message be sent to the Senate stating that-

(1) the request is irregular in that it seeks to have the House resume consideration of a Bill which lapsed at the dissolution of the House of Representatives and in respect of which the resumption of proceedings is effectively prevented by the standing orders of the House and accepted parliamentary practice;
(2) the House does not intend to resume consideration of the Bill as requested; and

(3) if the Senate desires the House of Representatives to consider the Bill, it is suggested that the Senate should introduce it again and transmit it to the House for concurrence in accordance with normal procedures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the 1990 Budget before the Parliament confirms our worst fears. The Government has lost any semblance of courage, of leadership and, indeed, of vision. The Budget is all about lowest common denominator factional politics-what is acceptable to people beyond the Parliament, what might or might not be acceptable to the special Labor Party conference due on 24 September, and what might be acceptable or not acceptable to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), which had plenty to say about what was not acceptable about the Telecom decision made yesterday by this Government. I note the ACTU is represented in the gallery this day.

SPEECH.PARA: In many respects the Australian economy can best be described as the Titanic. I do not mean titanic as in large, but rather I am referring to that splendid vessel which sank so disastrously earlier this century. This Budget is all about tinkering on the Titanic, and the designer of the Australian Titanic, the Australian economy, is the Federal Treasurer (Mr= Keating).

Like the naval architects who designed the SS Titanic, the Treasurer has designed his own Titanic based on flawed assumptions. The designer of the SS Titanic assumed that the strength of the ship's hull and its watertight compartments would make it unsinkable. The Treasurer has continued to assume much the same in relation to the economy. However, the reality is that by virtue of this Budget, the Treasurer has set a course which, simply stated, is all about `steady as she sinks'.

In that context I thank the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) for pointing out that Australia is moving in that particular direction, because that is where the Australian ship of state, the Australian economy, is heading; this Budget is all about `steady as she sinks'.

My experience in travelling across the length and breadth of Australia in recent times is that we are fast reaching the point where our normally resilient economy, our normally resilient farmers, miners, small business operators and blue-collar workers can take it no longer. There is massive economic agony across Australia reflected by increased bankruptcies, higher unemployment and even increased use of food vouchers issued by such organisations as the Salvation Army.

TALK.START.PARA: —People are just walking out of their businesses.

—Indeed. There is another category, where they are not actually bankrupt, but where small business operators are simply closing their doors and walking away from their small business operation because of the rapid and massive economic downturn impacting across so much of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's economic policies are in many ways to blame for this. Its other policies, where it has tinkered, where it has dawdled on key decisions, are also to blame. Like the SS Titanic, the Australian economy is in danger of sinking without a trace.

There will be one man who will bear the burden of responsibility for this disaster, and that is the Treasurer. I say to the House that on 28 July 1990 the Treasurer did liken the economy to a ship. He said:
You know, when you turn the economy around it is like turning around a big ship. You turn the wheel and a long way further the vessel starts to turn.
The trouble with the Treasurer's ship is that it is a case of `steady as she sinks'. It is not turning; it is sinking, and it is sinking rapidly.

The most telling criticism of the 1990 Budget is that there was an opportunity to address these problems. What was needed were policies which would bring down inflation, bring down the value of the Australian dollar and allow interest rates to trend down sustainably. The opportunity was lost as the Treasurer dished out more of the same and, indeed, with a sting in the tail. Let us look at one particular aspect: the question of an anti-inflation policy contained in this Budget. People who live in New South Wales and consume gas might be interested to know that buried in the detail of this Budget is a commitment by the Federal Government to legislate for not one but two 25 per cent increases in the tariff on gas moving along the pipeline from the field at Moomba to Sydney. That tariff is to be legislated for totally contrary to an existing agreement between Australian Gas Light Co. and the Pipeline Authority.

Worse still, the Government has issued a letter, which I am happy to read part of to the House today, in which it insists that `with the passage of this legislation, you will be required to pass on the two lots of 25 per cent increases to the consumers'. Let me quote exactly. It comes from the Government Task Force on Asset Sales of the Department of Finance:
AGL will be required to pass on in full these increases in haulage tariffs to gas consumers but will be free to decide for itself just how this might be done.

With regard to this aspect of the Budget, two legislated-for increases of 25 per cent in this tariff do nothing for the Government's anti-inflation policy. The coalition will be examining this legislation very carefully when it comes forward. Indeed, there is a hole in the middle of the Budget, and I acknowledge the description by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) that it is a doughnut Budget. It is lacking in any substantial progress on micro-economic reform and, indeed, on privatisation, notwithstanding the most recent developments.

In dealing with the Budget I would like to highlight to the House that for the first time total revenue to the Commonwealth Government will exceed $100 billion. In fact, the Budget provides for an all time record revenue of $101.1 billion and an expenditure of $93 billion and, therefore, a surplus of $8.1 billion. Income tax payments continue to rise in gross amounts. Let me highlight the extent of these income tax rises, notwithstanding so-called income tax cuts from next January. Overall revenue from income tax is expected to rise from $50 billion to $54.3 billion, an increase of 8.7 per cent in gross income tax takings. When we include company tax, superannuation funds taxation, withholding tax, resource rent tax and fringe benefits tax, we have a total increase of revenue in this broadly defined category from $65.4 billion to $69.8 billion, an increase of 6.7 per cent on the previous year.

The Federal Government's revenue figure in the Budget-some $101 billion overall-comprises some $70 billion from income tax broadly defined, whereas only $19.7 billion comes from indirect taxes such as sales tax, petroleum excise and customs import duty. I might add that this still represents a massive taxation burden, particularly for fuel users, for example, and especially those who are using fuel in respect of export industries.

Australian Federal Budgets of recent years have affirmed a massive tilt towards direct tax payments, particularly individual income tax, with less reliance on indirect taxation. That is why blue-collar workers are walking out of trade unions in such large numbers, why the membership of trade unions has declined in so many industries. In fact they are being slugged, and that is why so many blue-collar workers are very unhappy with the income tax system and the marginal rates that exist today.

Let us look back. In 1985-86 income tax accounted for 65.9 per cent of the revenue base of the Federal Budget. Today it comprises over 70 per cent-in fact, around 72 per cent of the revenue base of this Budget. In this context, I point out to the House that the Treasurer said on 9 June 1985:

Australia faces a clear choice. It either does something about the high marginal rates impacting on average weekly earnings and finds another base in the tax system or it does not, but we must stop dealing with symptoms. The tax laws are in need of radical surgery.
That was the Treasurer, Paul Keating. He went on to say, on 4 June 1985:

We need to reduce the current over-reliance on the income tax base. This would result in a manifestly fairer tax system and would create the foundations for a more efficient system to promote stronger economic growth and higher living standards.

So we have the Treasurer, back there in 1985, arguing for a shift in the tax base of the Budget, but we have a Budget before the House today which reaffirms the massive reliance on income tax from individuals, effectively sucking out enterprise and initiative and reward for effort in a way which is clearly denting the performance of the Australian economy.

Let me say that there is an alternative, and this is what I want to dwell on: the clear-cut choice being offered by the coalition with regard to this aspect of taxation. The Liberal and National parties have adopted the goods and services tax (GST) package which I want to detail. It provides for, firstly, the total abolition of the present inefficient and unfair system of wholesale sales tax; secondly, the introduction of a broadly based goods and services tax; thirdly, the provision of a rebate from the goods and services tax on all business imports and a zero rating of exports; fourthly, the provision of rebates on GST on fuels used in business and farming; fifthly, provision of compensation packaged to include low income earners, pensioners and others; and sixthly, finally and very importantly, significant and substantial personal income tax cuts flowing from our goods and services tax package.

That is the clear-cut alternative for the tax structure of this country. We have had the courage to bite the bullet and to provide a very real alternative which will put incentive back into our economy. It will do one other thing: it will abolish the $1 billion to $2 billion of indirect taxes currently being applied to our export industries in a crippling way at a very difficult time for export performance, given the value of the Australian dollar and the related value of Australian interest rates. We have made a commitment to abolish totally the wholesale sales tax regime with all its anomalies. It taxes at 20 per cent a blue-collar worker with his tool box heading off to Mount Isa Mines but does not tax anyone heading into Parliament House wearing an Italian suit in terms of sales tax-and so many more anomalies could be given. We will abolish completely that wholesale sales tax and, in so doing, we will provide a system which puts our exporters on a similar footing to 21 out of the 24 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. At the moment they are being penalised by from $1 billion to $2 billion by the current hopeless system of taxation provided for once again in this Budget. There is a clear-cut choice, a clear-cut alternative on the matter of taxation.

Of course, we also have a clear-cut alternative on privatisation, and I want to dwell on Telecom. The Government is stranded on privatisation. It is paralysed. It has gone for the lowest common denominator politics-factional politics, conference controlled politics, and I note all those who are present in the chamber at this time. On the matter of Telecom let me say to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) that, in effect, what he argued for this afternoon was the backdoor sleazy method of provision of cross-subsidisation to facilitate some Telecom activity across country Australia and, indeed, in city Australia. The community service obligation (CSO) does not relate just to provincial Australia, remote Australia and regional Australia; it also relates to Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and beyond. It is a very important question.

The coalition decided as a clear-cut choice to identify that community service obligation once and for all and to do so fairly. At the moment Telecom does not credit the rural network with all the income it raises and, consequently, the CSO figure is much larger than it actually might be. But we have given a commitment to identify that community service obligation. We have given a commitment and accept that the Federal Government has a responsibility to ensure a comprehensive network across Australia. We also accept that that should be done at a reasonable cost. The alternative, under the Government's decision yesterday, is that we are going to continue with a backdoor method of cross-subsidisation. We are going to continue to provide for that by bureaucratic fiefdom, by decision of bureaucrats. I can point to towns around Australia which have ancient automatic telephone exchanges, which have enormous difficulties under the approach by this Government over the last seven years, and which are not in a sense getting a fair chop out of the current CSO situation.

We have taken a more courageous and honest approach. We are going to quantify that, provide for it, put it up front in the Budget-and that is as it should be. I will not accept any system which will lessen the quality and fairness of access of rural and regional Australians to an adequate communications system. They must have that access at reasonable cost over the long haul of the 1990s and, given all the changes taking place in this decade, it is the approach to that issue taken by the coalition which has a better chance of delivering such a service and making it accountable to both the Parliament and the nation than the somewhat sleazy backdoor method that the Minister for Transport and Communications recommends.

The third and final area where we offer a clear-cut choice compared to what is offered in the Budget before the House-a Budget which is all about tinkering on the Titanic-is the area of uranium policy. For several years, the Government has pursued the hypocritical policy of three mines which, following the recent closure of one mine in the Northern Territory, has in fact come back to a one-mine policy. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) goes round saying, `You cannot govern the country if you cannot govern yourselves'. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said the other day on the matter of uranium policy that it drags on and on because the Australian Labor Party cannot take a decision. Here is an admission, from the Prime Minister's own lips and confirmed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, that the Government cannot govern the country.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy went on to say that the Government's current policy states that uranium should not be mined but also that uranium should be mined. So the Government is completely and utterly hypocritical as regards its two- or three-mine policy. The Government ought to own up and have the courage to put the issue on the agenda for the special conference. A special committee has been looking at this issue for over two years. The honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) is involved with that committee. Perhaps that is the reason that the committee has not got around to producing some form of report, or perhaps its attempts at producing a report have been vetoed. The Government has had over two years to put that report forward, take it to the special conference and resolve its major problem over uranium.

I do not often follow what Mr R. Hogg has to say, but he greatly impressed me on Sunday morning when he suggested that the Government had been wrong on its uranium policy and that its policy was inconsistent. Mr R. Hogg, who is a left-winger par excellence and perhaps someone that the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) is happy to be closely associated with, said that the mining policy of the Government is inconsistent. I will spare the Minister on this occasion.

Australia has a very stark choice. We face a desperate economic situation throughout the 1990s. This decade has started with economic agony unfolding right across the nation. The challenge for the Government was to come up with a Budget which made the fundamental decisions necessary to provide vision and leadership for this country and to review those policies which it knows in its heart it has got wrong. The Government's uranium policy is one of those policies.

We offer a clear-cut alternative with regard to uranium, which is simply that the artificial restrictions as proposed by Labor policy should be withdrawn. Our policy provides for the removal of the veto on new uranium mines. In fact, mining and the export of uranium will be permitted subject to environmental controls and strict international safeguards.

Australia has 28 per cent of the low cost uranium reserves. The left wing and others on the Government side would like to see that remain locked up when countries in Europe require over 70 per cent nuclear power in order to generate electricity so as to stop people from dying from cold in the winter.
