The 1990s may prove a period of less buoyant investment returns, which mean it is not a good time for employees to move from a defined benefit to an accumulation scheme because . . . the employees bear the investment risk.
This recent example of an employer on my electorate's doorstep graphically shows the realism of industrial relations rather than the pastoral landscapes portrayed by new right ideologies.

The same paper on 29 August reported another aspect of this bright future. In response to valid ACTU concerns of inconsistency in Industrial Relations Commission decisions and a campaign to accomplish the accord mark VI, employers met at the Confederation of Australian Industry and proposed to penalise the less militant unions that had not accomplished their claims. This was the big stick. One questions how reasonable employer responses would be in the absence of strong national industry unions.

Australia's centralised wage system, despite the limitation of the country's Constitution, has meant that firms competing in similar industries are not severely undermined by less scrupulous employers. It has meant that the peculiarities of State labour markets are not dominant in destroying local wages and conditions. It has ensured that, despite frequent government intervention, there has been some connection between the price movements that workers have suffered and their wage packets.

Recent revelations of Queensland's voluntary agreements could be compared to people rummaging through the dustbin and files of East Germany's Stasi Secret Police to get the facts. They demonstrate why the Greiner Government tried to make it virtually a capital offence to reveal details of its much vaunted voluntary agreements. They are simply a recipe to smash conditions and rights-freedom to be exploited.

No-one can seriously believe that understaffed, underfinanced workshop based unions have a serious negotiating parity with employers. The areas of intense labour shortage where that would be viable are extremely limited. The New South Wales Government's recent suggestions typify the suppression heralded by the supposed thrust for freedom. They are the model for Federal conservatives. The 25= May elopement of the Greiner Government with the Gallagher Builders Labourers Federation exposed the humbug of their facade of individual freedom, anti-corruption and respect for legalities. The recent legislative effort was a naked attempt to cast aside any vestiges of protection for the unorganised, the less skilled and the poor.

Amongst the suggested gains that New South Wales workers will experience are the abolition of the annual leave loading, the end of many penalty rates, localised site agreements with conditions below established awards and immediate stand-downs without the current need to establish that labour cannot be productively utilised. Attacks on work site safety rights follow fast on WorkSafe Australia statistics of 200 building workers' deaths between 1982 and 1989. Certainly there are tears and laments by conservative politicians after the more traumatic, newsworthy catastrophes. However, the assault on the building industry's safety precautions in the name of productivity is the reality. It starkly contrasts with Federal Labor's recent safety induction scheme, workers' manual and kit trainers' guide and dispute settling procedure. That the conservatives were going through the motions with the Niland inquiry is shown by the swift abandonment to the dustbin of this limited area for industrial action.

As detailed earlier, the Hawke Labor Government's period of office has been accompanied by a decline in real earnings, as typified by the Treasury Roundup of Economic Statistics showing that the non-farm wage share has fallen from 64.9 per cent of production to 57.6 per cent since 1983. Even from the period 1985-86, the profit share has grown from 14.8 per cent to over 17 per cent. Certainly, this is related to the vulnerability of the union movement, economic recession and government imperatives.

However, it has also spelt out the crucial role of the accord and the recognition by the ACTU of national needs. Certainly, there have been gains such as the Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act, industrial relations reforms, social wage improvements, wider application of superannuation and Government initiatives towards amalgamations. The latter is a desired move of much of industry, albeit by different approaches.

Nevertheless, the principal impetus was the recognition of Australia's dire trade balance and the continued decline of value added goods within our exports. The most recent figures indicating the patchy gains in this sector, despite promised investment with augmented profits, must place continued union compliance under great strain.

We are asked to make the attack on foreign debt and servicing a priority justifying national sacrifice. For how long will the public be prepared to do so when four major corporations' contribution to net foreign debt totals $15 billion? Can members of the public respect the illogicality of moves to privatise Telecom Australia, thus endangering native equipment manufacture in the crucial communications and informations sector where $4 billion of our trade deficit lies and is certain to grow even without this counterproductive measure?

This year has witnessed some positive trends in the trade picture. A March quarter rise in manufactured imports followed an underlying trend of slower import growth and parallels and a 11.5 per cent increase in manufactured exports above the previous year's level. The manufacturing investment has been on a more diverse front than earlier surges. For the June quarter, seasonally adjusted import values fell by 11 per cent, and there were signs of improvement in non-metal manufactured goods. July witnessed a tenth growth in imports, and some commentators feared that this might be more relevant than previous trends because of an underlying reduction in raw materials at hand. Additionally, fears have been expressed that the direction has not been towards new capacity for exports and countering imports but to replace and update plant in existing patterns. Unfortunately, much of it has centred on the financial services sector, instanced in tourism and not internationally traded.

Nevertheless, it has to be asked whether the impact of higher interest rates is undermining the supposed gains of the diversion from wages to profits. How long can the union movement hold the line? While it does, a recent copy of Australian Society reports work on the Australian Bureau of Statistics 1986 income distributor survey by Andrew Dilnot. It detailed an estimate of 19.7 per cent of wealth in the hands of the richest one per cent and 55.2 per cent possessed by the wealthiest tenth of the population. The bottom half hold less than 2 per cent. In that article, Andrew Dilnot also covers the regressive nature of the taxation of savings and notes the amount of progressivity required of other parts of the tax system to counter it.

Additionally, expectations by the union movement regarding a cooperative restructuring of the industrial base, real industrial democracy, retraining, an investment fund to set redirection, et cetera, have not been realised. I cite Vic Taylor in the Journal of Australian Political Economy, April 1990, at page 44, when he noted that, instead, we have the push for `enterprism which pays no attention to strategic level institutions' and would seek `to put in place communications programs and personnel measures designed to enhance micro-corporatist tendencies and to mould enterprise union organisation into user-friendly entities'.

Despite these questions, the accord represents a preferable course to a regime of market forces dominance, wage break-outs, inflation, unemployment and wage freezes. This has been the sad history of conservative industrial relations. The accord signals an attempt to garner diverse forces for the national interest. It contains national wage outcomes in expectation of gains in social wage, trade relations, career paths and investment policy. It represents an overdue initiative to balance economic imperatives with equity. The alternative is uncharted and advocated by people who, today, simultaneously rush to join the Norm Gallagher rehabilitation club. Apparently, his stance of violence and intimidation is to be condoned as long as it serves corporate imperatives.

In a free society, industrial relations must entail a degree of compromise. Without the suppression of liberties implicit in the Howard-Hewson industrial relations agenda, neither side can expect overwhelming superiority. It is, therefore, interesting to note the survey in the Confederation of Australian Industry publication the Employer for July 1990. We all know that employers and unions have wish lists. Both forces have their realists, and I dare say that they would be fairly prevalent in the surveyed group. It is reassuring for our system that 70 per cent of those who thought that broad banding would aid productivity thought change was achievable by late 1991.

Admittedly, on a more partisan subject, such as treating weekends as ordinary hours, only 21.6 per cent of the 45.8 per cent who felt it necessary were as confident. However, any person who does not believe that El Salvador-Guatemala style industrial relations is the best road would be fairly comfortable with figures of 56.4 per cent for adherence to awards, 42.5 per cent for sick leave, 55.8 per cent for new training and 73.8 per cent for multi-skilling.

Whilst there are limited absolutes and all economies suffer international realities, an article in the European Industrial Relations Review of February 1990 indicated a more pronounced development of an accord process. It detailed Sweden's efforts and, admittedly, some of the worrying down side, including a trend to overseas subsidiary diversion of research, the dilution of the solidarity wage policy by profit sharing and employee loans and emphasis on overseas investment. Nevertheless, Sweden's policy has resulted in a low 1.3 per cent unemployment rate, which is a seventh of the unemployment rate of France and a quarter of West Germany. Its wages policy has answered inflation with an equity of wages across industry, forcing unprofitable enterprises to cease.

Sweden's 1988 labour market programs, according to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, meant a level of expenditure trailing only Spain and France in active endeavours, that is, employment services, training, youth measures and employment subsidies. In contrast, this leads to a situation where, with the low unemployment figures, its income maintenance efforts are the nadir of relative labour market efforts. Relocation assistance for industrially moribund areas has been stressed. Equally, the government business partnership has ensured that prosperous firms direct some employment to deprived areas, and there has been State intervention to enhance socially desirable but financially plagued operators. A series of reports from external credible sources has detailed a combination of very minimal unemployment, constricted inflation and a consolidated national budget. It has been accompanied by a singularly successful placement policy for trainees.

The challenge for Australia is to overcome the constraints of traditional thought of a limited role for government in planning and industrial policy. Unfortunately, recent decisions stressing self-regulation in major resource projects, rather than active government monitoring of local content, appear to be a recipe for minimal gains. A shift of profits has been no guarantee of an expanding export sector. The Government must harness government enterprises to provide management skills, a history of achievement on complex projects and pools of expertise to ensure a reasonable native component in measures to really do something about the value added sector. I am proud that the Budget's industrial relations component has greater funding for the workplace reform program, encouragement of amalgamations, a further encouragement of the integration of our State and Federal systems and work on equal pay and award adherence.

I have spoken earlier of the pressures on the accord and concerns about its future. On other fronts the last election spelled a recognition of Labor accomplishments, accomplishments that the electorate earlier this year knew were threatened by the hostility or mismanagement of the Opposition. Foremost is Medicare. Its establishment in 1984 spelled adequate health care for two million people previously denied. The misery of a United States style system of class based discrimination ceased. This was definitely threatened by an interest group dominated Opposition whose health policies have since been decried in the distancing antics of many Opposition spokesmen. Medicare has entailed a certainty of funding, with an appreciation of the link to the ageing of our population. A massive increase has occurred in the numbers treated in our hospitals. The Medicare incentives scheme has engineered growth of day surgery, palliative care and at-home convalescent care.

In this Budget major initiatives for training and support of rural general practitioners and improvements in their visits to nursing homes and for emergency after-hours surgery are covered. Schedule fee increases are restrained and the gap is to be relative to that which applied in November 1986. I commend moves on the methadone program and AIDS containment. My own electorate has a disproportionately high aged population-a factor of the 1950s Housing Commission settlement, subsequent pensioner unit construction, and transport proximity. Labor's thrusts to widen the options for the aged and extend the availability of hostel style accommodation are vital. Similarly, our assurance that by mid-1991 no nursing home resident will pay greater than 87.5 per cent of pension has wide support from these people and their families. Regional geriatric assessment services are expanded, dementia grants increased by two-fifths and conversion of self-contained flats to hostel style units encouraged. Recurrent funding will be investigated to analyse its relationship with the needs of more dependent residents.

The home and community care program epitomised by recent vital grants to the Holroyd municipality for community transport for respite to carers was a Labor triumph of 1984-85. Australia must appreciate the demographic realities that determine an expansion of domiciliary services over a broad front-meals on wheels, home aid, et cetera-and governments must recognise both here and in child-care that the work force has awoken from willing exploitation in the name of humanitarianism. Increasingly, these industries are being associated with greater training and knowledge, with more standardised hours and career paths. The spread of child-care, so vital to industry policy and planning, with home care, has represented a bastion of underpayment and exploitation. Concern with wages growth has to be questioned in the context of a more informed and organised work force. When we speak of child-care we are touching on another area where the reality of the rabble opposite was exposed in a mishmash of contradictory statements.

Labor, in contrast, could approach the electorate with a 25 per cent funding rise. It could legitimately claim to be on target for 122,000 places by January next year. It retained credibility when it heralded incentives for industry to move into the field and spoke of a priority for working-class families. Many of the criteria used in priorities for government funded child-care centres are very proper and particularly relevant to my electorate. This Budget means a major increase in fee relief and a related rise in maximum benefit. Additional to the 50,000 non-profit community child-care places will be an expansion of employer provided facilities and further private commercial operators. Fee relief will flow to 90,000 new families. The maximum fee relief of $85 will flow to non-renters with one child who have incomes up to $370 per week. The taper will be adjusted from 17c per dollar for one child and 23c for two, to 10c and 20c respectively. The Opposition is somewhat embarrassed by the expansion of child-care places from 46,000 when it lost government to a level of 250,000 in 1995-96. These moves are crucial to Australia's prosperity and crucial to our employment participation levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call on the honourable member for North Sydney, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the first time in many years the voters of an electorate have sent someone to this House with no ties to a party, to preselectors or to a special interest group. The electorate has given notice that safe seats are becoming a thing of the past and is delivering a message that many in this House will not want to hear. The community has taken the rhetoric of competition and deregulation at face value and is now applying it, to use today's jargon, to the political duopoly.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been sent here not only because of dissatisfaction with the Australian political system but also because for a decade the electors of North Sydney have experienced a new and better way of running public affairs-a way that is founded on the principle that people whose lives are affected by a decision must be part of the process of arriving at that decision; a way that delivers a new kind of open, accountable, participatory democracy with expanded public services and reduced taxation; a way that has no place for the secret, centralised decision making by executives of political parties in combination with powerful, unelected, unaccountable interest groups that is now the dominant process in a largely self-serving Australian political system.

These ideas are not unique to North Sydney. They began in the 1960s and are buffeting monopolies around the world, whether they be commercial, bureaucratic or political. The forces of change and the ethic of participation do not recognise national boundaries. The recent political upheavals of eastern Europe are no accident. It is also no accident that this Government is the most minority government since Federation, with only 39.4 per cent of the vote; that the membership of political parties is collapsing; that 17 per cent of Australians voted against the major parties; that the number of non-party members has virtually doubled each election in the 1980s in New South Wales; that the Senate has not been controlled by the Government since 1981, and will never be again; that the New South Wales upper House lost executive dominance in 1988; and that the first lower House in Australia not to be dominated by one party has come into existence in Tasmania.

It would be easy to ascribe these events to the steady slide in social, economic and environmental conditions in the past 20 years; to the increasingly overt nepotism, careerism, cronyism and corruption in our political system highlighted by the Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland and the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales. It would be easy to ascribe it to the cynical multimillion dollar advertising campaigns; to the broken promises; to the blatant centralisation of public decision making; to big business, big unions, big government; to the flaunting of wealth by entrepreneurs in the 1980s, the record sales of Mercedes, the officially sanctioned tax rorts; to bigger salaries for politicians, free cars all round, more overseas trips with increasing retinues at five-star hotels while the general public is told they are living beyond their means, that they have got to work harder and have to tighten their belts.

Our traditional political duopoly and administrative structures are failing. It is not just a problem of a few bad apples. The system is not delivering and a large section of the community is irrevocably alienated. It may seem unfair that the former member for North Sydney had to bear the brunt of all this, but it is certain that in the future there will be further casualties. What sort of future does this small country have with nine governments, 15 Houses of Parliament, 855 politicians and their associated overlapping bureaucracies spewing out truckloads of legislation each year-much of it well-meaning but cumulatively self-defeating? It is a shambling structure derived from a century-old parochial compromise corrupted by unelected interest groups, party executives, an elitist private-not public-service, and gerrymandered voting systems. An anachronistic lunacy in which all political parties had a vested interest was the description applied to it by our present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) some years ago. That may be true, but an increasing number of people are beginning to have other ideas.

Does anyone really think Australia can be legitimately run by a Government that commands only 39.4 per cent of the vote but 52.7 per cent of the seats in this House and where 17 per cent of voters who did not vote for the major parties were rewarded with 0.7 per cent of the seats? It may be democracy the Bjelke/Richardson way but it is a long way from any notion of fairness or a real expression of the will of the people.
Quite apart from the gerrymander, most people are aware that this House has little public purpose. As a former Clerk of the House, J. A. Pettifer, said in 1979:
The party system has overwhelmed the Westminster system and destroyed its original checks and balances.

A decade later the McIntosh study confirmed that even 80 per cent of the members of this House believe that it is simply a rubber stamp. Legislation, decided mostly by the unelected in private, is agreed to as a formality. There is no separation of executive and parliament; no real accountability of the executive or bureaucracy, which is fundamental to the democratic system. Advocates of the reform of parliament have suggested such titivations as additional staff for members, more private members time, procedural reform, an expanded committee system, longer sitting times, more free votes, televising of Parliament, and electronic voting. As for the latter, the simplest system would be for only the party whips and myself to vote-and, of course, any party member who wishes to commit harikari by crossing the floor.

All of these so-called reforms avoid the issue. The issue is control of Parliament by five or six people through the rigid party system. This was starkly confirmed recently when only about five phone calls were necessary to commit our defence forces to a possible war in the Middle East. The issue is centralisation of power and government by special interest and elitism to the point where probably 142 of 148 members of this House, and certainly the public, have little or no input into public decision making, except for a little `chook feeding' by way of pacification.

There is, of course, no suggestion that things would be much different if a change of government occurred. The Opposition in this House is only a more disorganised version of the Labor Party in terms of centralised power. The fact is that after nine elections in 18 years, the community has learnt that government by rejection is comparatively futile. A change of government means more of the same, irrespective of election rhetoric.

Our two-airline political system not only is failing to deliver, but also is working consistently against building public support and consensus for the necessary restructuring if Australia is going to compete in the global village. Dr Ian Marsh of the Australian Graduate School of Management encapsulated the position when he recently stated:

. . . issues can never be discussed short of a challenge to the competence of the current government-Parliament can never debate major strategic issues without partisan allegiances coming to the fore.

Parliamentary committees in other democratic countries can initiate major structural changes on a consensus basis. Here such committees are carefully husbanded to relatively minor tasks by ministerial advisers with the blessing and manipulation of Sir Humphrey and his legions.

Two-party politics creates an almost overwhelming imperative for oppositions to pander to sectional selfishness and, as a result, constrain themselves should they gain the government benches. Incentives to oppose are multiplied, differences are magnified and spurious choices are falsely propagated. The reversal of party positions on the consumption tax issue is a stark example of the sterile and hypocritical nature of the adversarial system.

The duopoly of the two-party system creates many distortions, such as the fiction that members can represent their electorates when ultimately they can only represent their party executives; the exclusion of most of the community from many key positions in the Public Service and in parliament as those positions are remorselessly filled with groupies, family and former ministerial staff; the continual faction and leadership struggles; the fiction that Ministers can also be local members; the fact that ministerial competence is largely accidental, given the present preselection process; and the increasing propensity of the political parties to fund their activities from the public purse.

Increasingly, governments are out of touch with the community. The multifunction polis, large-scale public asset disposal, woodchipping of native forests, the failure to stop major drug promotion and exploitation, foreign ownership, immigration policy, and $900,000 dining rooms are but a few examples of where Government policies did not have majority support, irrespective of the merits of such policies.

The point is that policy can no longer be driven by special interest and elitism. It can only be effectively arrived at and implemented by public participation in the decision-making process. The common and cynical assumption among the elite is that the necessary hard decisions for change can only be taken against the popular will and must be taken by stealth, and taken early, so that the public will have time to either forget them or appreciate their inherent wisdom before the next election. This assumption shows contempt for the public and the democratic system and it just does not work.

Reform must commence with the acceptance by government and its bureaucracies of the fundamental principle of democracy, which is that a decision made by the whole community will be right more often than a minority decision taken by an elite group, no matter how wise or altruistic. No group has a mortgage on wisdom or values. Reform must recognise that the system of delegating all rights to a representative or political party every three or four years and then passing judgment on that representative or party is futile. The growth of education, the information explosion and the rate of change have fundamentally made the representative system ineffective and even unnecessary.

People must be part of the decision-making process whenever it affects them. We must shift to participatory democracy through a whole range of mechanisms, such as greater use of referendums and acceptance of the people's right to initiate and even veto legislation. The traditional propensity of government and the Public Service to secrecy must be reversed, with an expansion of freedom of information and openness at all levels of administration. The Ombudsman's powers should be widened and public scrutiny and accountability improved at all levels of executive and bureaucratic administration and policy making. The present restriction on freedom of information by exorbitant charges and manipulation of privacy provisions must be eliminated.

If principles such as these were adopted, effective electoral, parliamentary and constitutional reform could commence. But if change is attempted on its traditional basis of seeking advantage on a party or personal basis, we will continue to create such pictures of Dorian Gray as the Australian Capital Territory Government. Government will continue to be distrusted and harassed at every turn. Unless governments-Federal, State or local-can command public respect and confidence, they are largely ineffective.

Most governments and representatives in Australia are held in increasing disrepute by the community. It affects all levels of administration and it will not be reversed by cosmetics. It can only be overcome by governments setting an example to the community, by controlling their self-serving nature, the `Taj Mahals', and the constant increases in lurks and perks which have permeated almost every level of Australian society, from the debauched tax system to the ritual overseas junket, reinforcing a `greed is good' materialist philosophy.

Electoral reform must be implemented, not on the basis of short term electoral advantage, but on the basis of fairness and one vote, one value. That means the eventual abandonment of our traditional gerrymanders and single member constituencies which constantly produce electoral distortions. The last Queensland election showed that even the worst traditional gerrymander pales into insignificance compared to single member seat distortion. Labor won 60 per cent of the seats with 50 per cent of the vote; the Nationals won three times as many seats as the Liberals with the same vote. Even after preference distribution, three minority Federal governments have been formed since 1961.

The only fair system operating in Australia is the Hare Clark system in Tasmania. Not only does it invariably reflect the will of the people, but it also eliminates how-to-vote distribution, by-elections, donkey voting and boundary manipulation, and enables the people as a whole to share in party preselection. What this means is parliament as a true reflection of a democratic, pluralist society and the end of executive domination. To avoid continual minority government and instability, the executive government should, ideally, be removed from parliament and elected directly by the people. Members of parliament could then represent their constituencies and a proper separation of powers and the monitoring of the executive could be achieved. The increasing non-party vote at all levels of government-local, State and Federal-over the last decade is the writing on the wall for reform and no amount of public relations or electoral manipulation will stop the trend.

With little public comment the Senate has been transformed. It was created at Federation as a States House but for most of its life it has been a party House. Now it is more representative of the community than the lower House. Yet the changing role of the Senate and its conversion to a people's House is marred by the massive gerrymander, with almost 13 New South Wales votes equalling one Tasmanian vote. Irrespective of whatever short term benefits exist in this situation, the present and likely future position of a meaningless lower House and an undemocratic Senate is not sustainable.

A great deal has been said about the need for rationalisation of the overlapping bureaucracies at the three levels of government and the need for uniform standards, particularly in respect of transport, corporate regulation, the environment and the legal system-all of which are certainly to be welcomed. The real surgery, however, is needed for the political and administrative structure. Constitutional reform will not come by any Whitlamesque version of centralised power imposed from above or dreams of the disappearance of the States. None of the three levels of government will or should disappear. There is always a national, a regional and a local interest which must be recognised but there is no reason why colonial State borders should leave so many genuine regions of Australia effectively unrepresented or why we need full-blooded, antiquated Westminster systems at State level.

The level of overgovernment and over-representation at State level is quite grotesque: 631 members of Parliament and their associated bureaucracies, an array of mouseketeers unparalleled in any other country. Any sensible reforms could at least halve this burden. Conversely, many of the bloated local government bodies on the perimeters of Sydney and Melbourne should be reduced to population units of around 50,000, at which level any real local government ends. The necessary redistribution of both power and functions must be based on decentralisation to the lowest appropriate level.

The shift to participatory democracy by such measures as direct election of prime ministers, premiers and mayors; the separation of executives and legislatures; increased use of referenda and citizen initiated referenda; electoral reform; fixed four-year terms of office and proper levels of representation together with maximum open government and public participation to build a consensus is the only possible way to reform.

A loss of trust in the nation's leaders and political system and a country edging towards economic and ethical bankruptcy-this is `the big picture' facing our community. It is a community with accelerating selfishness, hedonism, crime, violence, vandalism, corporate fraud, tax fraud, insurance fraud, welfare fraud and corruption at all levels-a society fracturing into tunnel vision, self-interest groups on a survival-of-the-fittest basis with centralisation of power and money on one hand and a rapidly developing underclass on the other.

Our political system offers us an endless cycle of short term solutions, cynical promises, tax bribes to strategic voting groups, selling the future to pay for today's excesses, ideological leaps into the unknown, futile adversary conflict, and electoral manipulation.

There are no national goals or directions and without these we are rudderless. We need a stocktake and a development of national goals based on common basic values and an understanding that transcends barriers of race, religion, sex or status with equity, justice and integrity.

These goals can only be reached by the involvement of the community as a whole, by a community that accepts individual responsibility and is willing to change direction and begin the process of reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith, I remind the House that the honourable member is making his maiden speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my case it has been a long spell between maiden speeches but I must say it is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise to support this motion for the adoption of the Federal Budget. At the outset, I wish to warmly thank the electors of Kingsford-Smith for the confidence they have shown in electing me to represent them in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: From boyhood I have aspired to what I consider the greatest of honours, that of carrying Labor's colours as its Parliamentary representative. To the rank and file membership of our great Party who bestowed this honour upon me, I wish to record my profound gratitude. My time in this House will be devoted to serving their interests and the high ideals of our Party.

My transition from State to national politics would not have been possible without the enormous assistance of my campaign director, Mr Pat Williams, who, as in so many earlier campaigns, never faltered in his professionalism. His personal guidance and the hard work of each member of the campaign team could not have been greater.

The burden of allowing me to pursue my political aspirations here in Canberra will be borne by my wife, Tricia, and young sons, Anthony and Christopher. I want to acknowledge their support and the personal sacrifice of family life which is involved.

On behalf of the people of Kingsford-Smith, I wish to pay tribute to my predecessor, the Honourable Lionel Bowen. For four decades Lionel devoted himself to serving his constituents, first in local government, then in New South Wales State politics and then as a member of this House. His legacy is of legendary dimension. No politician could depart public life more widely admired. No Prime Minister could have had a finer deputy to support him.

In 1968 I nominated for ALP preselection for Kingsford-Smith with a view to succeeding the then retiring member, Dan Curtin. I subsequently withdrew that nomination in favour of Lionel Bowen and went instead to take Lionel's place in the Legislative Assembly of New South Wales. After more than 20 years it gives me a great deal of pleasure to take my place here in this chamber. When asked, I have likened it to finally being promoted to the first division.

In this, the highest political forum in the land, there can of course be no greater issue to discuss than the direction of national economic policy as set out in the annual Budget. While some commentators would have us believe that there has been a narrowing of the differences between the major parties, the debate over the 1990 Budget dispels this notion. For once again, the traditional differences over the role of government and how its responsibilities should be financed are plain for all to see.

Significant divisions relating to fiscal, monetary and wages policies stand out. In 1990 it is instructive to compare the past seven years of Labor rule with the previous seven years of coalition government.

For whilst the Opposition would like us to ignore history, our Government policies must be viewed against the background of the economic mess we inherited from the coalition in 1983. The Australian economy had experienced negative growth for the previous 12 months, with unemployment over 10 per cent, inflation running at over 11 per cent and the forward estimates forecasting a Budget deficit of $9.6 billion for the 1982-83 financial year.

The Opposition would have the Australian electorate believe this is irrelevant and yet, seven years on, I see the architects of that disastrous period-the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard)-taking pride of place in the supposedly revitalised Opposition benches.

The role of the honourable member for Bennelong as shadow Minister for industrial relations, is particularly ironic given that it was he as Treasurer who presided over the wage explosion of 1981-82 which so exacerbated the following year's downturn. Having left it to our Government to correct their mistakes, they now seek a second chance.

In 1983, our Government was elected with a mandate to revitalise the economy. It was epitomised by our campaign theme, `recovery, reconstruction and reconciliation'. The latter referred to the Accord, which was to form the basis of a new era of industrial peace and wage moderation, a new era vital if the benefits of recovery were not to be dissipated by another 1982 style wages explosion.

Experience shows that the Accord has been extremely successful in achieving those dual objectives of industrial peace and wage moderation. Industrial disputation has been at record lows, real unit labour costs have declined and in more recent times productivity has been boosted by the elimination of many of the restrictive work practices. As a result, employment growth reached unprecedented levels with 1.6 million new jobs created in that seven years.

When one stops to consider the context in which wage moderation was achieved, the merits of the Accord are even greater; for our seven years in Government have been characterised by economic growth rates well in excess of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average. Although this stemmed initially from a fiscal injection by the Government, in latter years we have seen the public sector to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio decline to early 1970 levels-that is, to levels which prevailed before the Fraser years.

This highlights how the Fraser economic team-the honourable member for Wentworth and the honourable member for Bennelong-shirked the tough spending decisions in spite of all the talk of razor gangs and the like. It seems to me that the razor was either blunt or it was directed to colleagues rather than spending programs.

Our fiscal policies in contrast-quite unlike those of Fraser-have involved concrete decisions rather than hollow rhetoric. Some of those decisions, such as the recent changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS), have not always been popular but they have always been fair.

In this Budget the results are there for all to see. We have a record surplus of $8.107 billion despite a cyclical downturn and despite the fact that the coalition handed us a $9.6 billion deficit just seven years ago. The ratio of government expenditure to gross domestic product sits at 23.5 per cent as opposed to the 30 per cent which prevailed in the last years of the Fraser Government. The ratio of revenue to GDP has fallen to 25.5 per cent, making Australia the third lowest taxing country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. All this has come from a government which has simultaneously boosted expenditure on science and education and indexed welfare benefits for those most in need.

The most important legacy of this fiscal turnaround has been to reduce the burden of government debt that future generations will face. This year the Commonwealth will repay $7 billion in debt and the ratio of Commonwealth debt to GDP will fall from 13.1 per cent to 10.5 per cent. The Government has to date repaid over $4 billion in foreign currency denominated debt, almost completely offsetting the $4.5 billion which was borrowed in the Fraser years. The resultant interest savings have enabled our Government to maintain a range of essential welfare benefits which the Leader of the Opposition comes into this House and says he wishes to destroy.

The Commonwealth's fiscal discipline has ensured that once again the public sector places no burden on private savings. Indeed the Hawke Government has made a zero public sector borrowing requirement an article of faith. In sticking to this commitment the Government has freed up savings for private sector investment. While the private sector has not always invested wisely, there is no doubt that the Government's discipline has helped to generate the spurt of private sector growth which has so characterised the 1980s.

Whilst this period of private sector expansion generated a rapid increase in employment and investment it also served to underline many of the structural deficiencies in the Australian economy, deficiencies neglected for years and years by do nothing conservative politicians. Indeed, many of these problems can be directly attributed to the policies of the Menzies-McEwen era. It was left to a Labor Government to face up to the reality of an Australia living beyond its means, relying on foreign savings and unprocessed primary exports to sustain inflated living standards. Our Government has been the first to recognise, let alone deal with, this reality and has taken positive measures to address it.

The rigid enforcing of public savings, the expansion of superannuation and the introduction of dividend imputation have all helped to improve our national savings performance. Meanwhile, the Government has sought to create an internationally competitive manufacturing sector by phasing out the McEwen style of protection and by rationalising the workplace through the accord process. We are now taking steps to improve the performance of public sector enterprises and proposing a major boost to expenditure on national infrastructure.

We have recognised that such an enormous transition of the Australian economy will take time and we have not bombarded the electorate with cheap, simplistic solutions. For that reason, the electorate has returned this Government again and again in the face of the cynical bribes and simplistic solutions proposed by the Opposition. Its recent attempts to portray a consumption tax, labour market deregulation and wholesale privatisation as the answer to all our problems show that the same old economic witchdoctors are still in business.

Not only are their solutions simplistic, they are often quite untenable. Nowhere is that better underlined than with the Opposition's proposal of late to sell Telecom to private interests for some $20 billion. The price tag is the equivalent of one-eighteenth of Australia's GDP and yet we are told that Telecom will not be sold to foreign interests. The reality is that such an outlay could be afforded only by foreign interests and Australia would inevitably lose sovereignty over its communications network. The difference between the realistic approach of our Government on these issues and the right-wing ideological commitment of those sitting opposite has never been more clearly defined.

The Opposition's favourite catchcry is deregulation, particularly where labour markets are concerned. Yet on the only occasions we have seen this practised in Australia a wage breakout has resulted. We are yet to be told by the Opposition why it will not happen again.

Self-regulation is that favourite catchcry of the business community which the Opposition likes to endorse, yet in recent years we have been treated to a number of examples of corporate greed which only underline the need for a vigilant government watchdog. In the form of the Australian Securities Commission, funded in this Budget, we will have such a body. However, the real thrust of any change has to be led by the great many honest businessmen in this country, for the standing of the business community and indeed the standing of the country as a whole has been tarnished by the unscrupulous and negligent activities of a number of high profile individuals.

We have heard and read much about the fundamentally dishonest activities of some entrepreneurs who have come unstuck in recent times. Yet in rightly condemning these unscrupulous individuals, we often overlook the role played by the bankers and the auditors. Whilst it would be stretching matters to describe them as accomplices, there is no doubt that many have been guilty of abject professional negligence.
On the role of auditors I need go no further than to quote the Australian Financial Review which recently observed:

For a large number of companies the accounts were absolutely meaningless . . . look at the companies that have gone broke. There were about $8 billion in shareholders' funds which were actually stated in the accounts, signed off by auditors, and subsequently disappeared.

The Australian Financial Review cited that figure of $8 billion as the actual loss in shareholders' funds, but the real cost in terms of investor confidence is impossible to quantify. For when the public reads that 66 per cent of Rothwells receivables consisted of personal loans to its chief executive-personal loans that he managed to shift off the balance sheet a day before balance date-they must surely question the reliability of the auditors who are supposed to monitor such irregularities. Alternatively, when they hear that much of the National Safety Council's listed assets consisted of mythical containers of safety equipment doubts inevitably arise about the accuracy of any of the financial information which is provided.

The fact that neither the auditors nor the bankers who loaned against the security of the empty containers bothered to check whether the equipment actually existed smacks of incompetence or just plain laziness. Either way, the professionalism of those involved has to be questioned.

The role played by the banks in nearly all of our corporate crashes has also been fundamental. Indeed, one of the most disgraceful features of the 1980s was the development of a regime of fee-driven banking by many of our corporate bankers. This regime was a lot more about structuring complex financial packages-they were packages to justify large up-front charges-than it was about ensuring that money was repaid. In the boom years it guaranteed large short term profits for the institutions involved while the bankers themselves were rewarded with huge salaries based on bonuses and commissions. As dependent as it was on a bull share market-and indeed an ongoing asset inflation-it was a regime unsustainable in the long run. Yet money continued to be lent without regard to capacity to repay. Of course, when the slowdown came the country was treated to the weekly spectre of one entrepreneur after another going to the wall.

Now we are being treated to the spectre of the banks making huge provisions for losses incurred on large loans to these same failed entrepreneurs. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) correctly observed, it is the banks' existing customers who suffer by being forced to pay higher interest rates while the banks attempt to recoup the losses made on these loans. By doing so, the banks are punishing others for their own breakdown in credit standing. The people who are really suffering today are those who are still in business and they are suffering every day at the hands of the banks.

In this period of fee-driven recklessness, the records of two high profile banks stand out above all the others. The first is that of the now infamous Tricontinental Ltd, which had the dubious distinction of achieving losses of $2.2 billion on a loan book of $3.8 billion. In the process, the bank's managing director was awarded the title of 1986 Young Executive of the Year. One can only speculate about what criteria were used to determine the winner of the award, but we can be certain of one thing: credit risk was not one of them.

The other bank which deserves particular recognition is the Hong Kong Bank of Australia Ltd. Its client base is like a who's who of the Australian corporate graveyard. Among them are George Herscu of Hooker Corporation Ltd, Brian Yuill of Spedley Securities Ltd, Lawrie Connell of Rothwells Ltd, Allan Hawkins of Equiticorp Tasman Ltd, John Friedrich of the National Safety Council of Australia-Victoria Division, Bruce Judge of Ariadne and Richard Lew of Estate Mortgage. In more recent times we had the same bank, the Hong Kong Bank, to thank for the financial package for the Harlin Holdings move on Elders IXL Ltd, a move which, of course, underlines the pitfalls of management buy-outs and has done so at the cost of the besieged former President of the Liberal Party. But for all of this the Bank's chief executive achieved an unprecedented salary in the boom years and was said to have earned commission of some $10m. Now that the fallout of these irresponsible lending practices is clear, all Australians are paying for the damage to our country's business reputation.

I have raised these matters in the time available to me today because they adversely affect the lives of all Australians. My own electorate of Kingsford-Smith covers much of the industrial heartland of Sydney. Here small business men and women are facing extortionate bank overdraft rates that threaten their very survival. Large manufacturing enterprises are facing a bank imposed credit squeeze which threatens their expansion, their investment plans and in many cases their very survival. Young couples are being forced to pay punitive home loan interest rates as the banks seek to protect their own bottom line. The electors of Kingsford-Smith want to see a fairer society, compassionate and caring for those most in need. They have sent me to Canberra to speak up on their behalf. It is my intention to do just that.
Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: — I thank the House. If anyone ever doubted the necessity of having such a guarantee in place, such doubts should have been cast aside by the recent civil warfare between the Xhosas and the Zulus, as they jockey for the dominant position as to which will have the major say in ruling South Africa. The Xhosas, through the African National Congress (ANC), seem to want a one-party state with them in charge, but Buthelezi's Zulus are not going to be denied their rightful slice of the action.

SPEECH.PARA: Because South Africa is almost uniquely complex in its ethnic, social and tribal groupings, we should not be surprised to see some unexpected results turn up in the ballot box in such an election. For example, the Asians, who have been very successful in South Africa and certainly know on which side their bread is buttered, could well side with the whites at voting time. Likewise, but for somewhat different reasons, the large coloured population may tend in this direction as well.

Naturally, the nine main black groupings will be expected to vote for their own candidates with, of course, the Zulus, totalling 7.3 million, comprising the major single group. Probably only after a negotiated coalition of alliances will anyone be able to claim a majority and a mandate to govern.

Regrettably, and unrealistically, the Australian Government does not see it that way. It says something about the deficiencies of this Government that, while the rest of the world is monitoring and encouraging these changes, we are pursuing an infantile, immature and out-of-date ideological policy that is hindering change rather than assisting it.

In his simple mind, Senator Evans portrays the problem as a struggle between conservative Afrikaaner whites on the one side and Mandela's left-leaning blacks on the other. I guess that is how out of touch one becomes when one refuses even to visit South Africa to see for oneself what is going on.

The blacks are made up of several distinct groups, all with different allegiances. The Zulus, led by Chief Mangosutho Buthelezi, are the biggest group, and their Inkatha movement has the largest membership of any organisation in South Africa. Naturally they must be a key element in any negotiated deal, but our Government not only ignores them but also has refused to have Buthelezi in Australia. No doubt this is because Buthelezi supports moderation instead of violence, espouses free enterprise instead of socialism and advocates free trade instead of sanctions. Such notions do not sit well with the radical socialist agenda the Australian Labor Party would like to see put in place in South Africa.

Although the vast majority of South Africans, including more than 80 per cent of blacks, according to opinion polls, are opposed to sanctions, our Government still supports such restrictions. Never mind that these very same sanctions hurt black people the most because it puts them out of jobs, destroys their chance to better themselves and condemns their families to poverty. That is not a serious consideration with members of this Labor Party.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) acknowledged and endorsed this very scenario when the Government funded and launched Colin Ovenden's book Apartheid in International Finance. A description of this very scenario can be found on page 187. The Government never realises that it is very wrong and patronising to peddle, from thousands of kilometres away, the fiction that blacks are all waiting breathlessly to give up their jobs just to further some imagined cause of Senator Evans. If this were the case surely they would have voluntarily given up their jobs long ago.

I have recently read a speech given by Helen Suzman regarding this very matter. I remind the House that during her 36 years as a member of the South African Parliament she opposed and voted against every apartheid measure to go through that Parliament. Her courage and foresight through those decades, long before apartheid became a trendy issue, is an example for us all.

Today, of course, the South African Parliament has repealed most of what was originally passed, much to the wry satisfaction of Helen Suzman. However, this remarkable woman adamantly claims that these changes have been largely due to the force of business and economic factors within South Africa, and not to sanctions, as this misguided Government and its coterie of small-minded advisers claim. In fact, many believe that sanctions and disinvestment, apart from hurting the black people themselves, and certainly not being wanted by most of them, are counterproductive in that they are making it harder to abolish apartheid. These ill-advised punitive measures are setting back the welcome reforms we are all so eager to see in South Africa.

It should be obvious that the political power and influence for the black majority is dependent on economic power. Ethiopia teaches us that. Any action which causes unemployment and poverty, and ultimately frustration and chaos, as our sanctions do, is another blow to black South Africa's emancipation. As Helen Suzman says, because of the violence and confrontation that poverty brings, more money is merely diverted from education and housing to the military and the police to retain law and order.

It is hard to think of another country nowadays that still applies sanctions as zealously as we do. In the light of recent reforms, Australia's foreign policy is especially antiquated and immature in comparison with those of other countries. Only two months ago, the President of Zambia, who is also chairman of the frontline states and who has possibly been South Africa's strongest critic, said he was lifting most of his country's remaining sanctions. The ban on the use of South African ports, as well as the ban on rail and road facilities, have all been lifted. Madagascar, another trenchant critic, has also announced it is to do the same, as well as inviting with open arms massive South African tourist investment and development into that country. South African Airways can again fly over that island. The Dutch Government is starting the orderly dismantling of sanctions and has relaxed visa regulations. Italy has eased trade restrictions and Denmark is restoring its ambassador to South Africa. Also Britain has lifted its voluntary ban on new investment.The European community is about to lift its ban on direct investment and its ban on imports of South African coal, steel and Kruger rands.

Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union are inviting South Africa into their markets. They have ceased funding the ANC and told it to solve its problems peacefully. Trade agreements have just been signed with Poland and Hungary. The Soviets have just entered into joint mining ventures with South Africa worth billions of dollars, including a $1 billion arrangement with diamond marketer de Beers. The Moscow Circus is also to tour South Africa.

Even intransigent Canada has had a visit from the South African Deputy Foreign Minister. It seems only Australia is continuing to endorse Senator Evans's quaint charade of affected morality. I was pleased to see the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), who is in the chamber tonight, recently call for the lifting of the petty ban on the issuing of visas from the Australian Embassy in Johannesburg. I was also pleased to see the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), call for the resumption of Qantas Airways Ltd and South African Airways flights between our two countries. I support these calls. After all it seems almost every other airline flies in and out of there. That includes British Airways, Lufthansa, KLM, Alitalia, Swissair, Varig, Sabena, Iberia, Luxair and others, not to mention many of the African airlines.

It is high time that some of the myths and hypocrisies about South Africa were exposed. A major one surrounds the role of Mr Mandela and the ANC which is not, I repeat not, the sole spokesperson or legitimate representative of black South Africa. The ANC is largely a Xhosa-based organisation, a group barely half the size of the Zulus. However, because it has been so violent and radical in the past it has become the darling of the Western media and the academic left. At the height of its notoriety it used to reign through fear as it had limited popular appeal and certainly minimal democratic power to give it its much needed legitimacy. It did this by `necklacing' other black people who did not comply with its wishes. For example, a black policeman or a shire employee, because they worked for the South African Government, would be regarded as collaborators. They would tie their hands behind their backs with wire, put a car tyre around their necks, fill it with petrol and set it alight. I have film of ANC cadres doing this to their own people.

It is not a pretty sight to watch ordinary decent citizens slowly being burnt to death in this way-screaming in pain, blinded, their eyes popping from the heat of the flames, knowing they will never again be with their loved ones. Mercifully, the frenzied crowd would often bounce half bricks or rocks off the victim's head, so hastening the unconsciousness that precedes death, while ANC flags were hoisted high in triumph by the perpetrators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—It is disgraceful. All this occurs while protesting against the inhumanity and excesses of the white government. Even the generally regarded more radical Pan-African Congress distanced itself from such brutal behaviour. Nelson Mandela's wife, Winnie, used to become quite excited at a necklacing. I can still see her in 1986 on a platform shouting, `With our boxes of matches and our necklaces we shall liberate this country'.

SPEECH.PARA: I went to her first house in Soweto in 1987. I believe it has since been burnt down. She was starting to build a new house just down the road where she lives now. It was believed to have cost something in excess of $US500,000. No doubt this woman is wondering whether or not she is to be called before the courts for her part in the torture and murder of the 14-year-old black youth Stompie Moeketsi Seipei. According to numerous reports, Winnie Mandela had what are called her `Mandela United Football Club' bodyguards, who have committed several acts of thuggery in Soweto, bring four youths to her house. Apparently they were kidnapped from a Soweto Methodist mission house. These youths were brutally assaulted in front of Mrs Mandela while she told them they `were not fit to be alive'. This was in late December 1988. One of the youths testified in court that Mrs Mandela beat him with a sjambok. Two of the others also claimed they were beaten and punched by her.

Three days after this assault took place, one of the youths, Stompie, was taken away and his partly decomposed body was found in a ditch some time later with three stab wounds in the neck. The `coach' of the Mandela Football Club, Jerry Richardson, has been charged with the murder and sentenced to death for his part in that offence. Forensic experts have testified that human blood was found on the seats of Mrs Mandela's minibus, on a whip taken from her house, and on the walls, floor and ceiling of two outside rooms. As honourable members can gather, the beatings must have been very violent.

I might add that another member of Winnie's football club, Charles Zwane, was only last week convicted of eight attempted murders, arson and illegally possessing a gun, as well as the more serious charge of nine murders, including that of a 13-year-old girl. Presumably, he will be sentenced to death too.

Naturally, Winnie Mandela is not too popular with the decent black people in Soweto. The South African Government is also placed in a difficult position, as it does not want Mrs Mandela's actions to jeopardise the delicate negotiations going on at present with the ANC. Her husband is not all that pure either. To westerners, Nelson Mandela is constantly painted as some sort of martyr hero who was wrongly gaoled for his noble actions and beliefs. How quickly the facts are forgotten. After joining the ANC in the early 1950s he soon became known for his radical left wing views. In 1953 he had accused the United States of America of genocide in Korea. In 1958 he wrote that the Marshall Plan was a US plot to gain control of the European economies. He even spoke of the `criminal and greedy appetites of the imperial powers'. He was appointed commander of the ANC's military wing in 1961, and he later underwent a military and revolutionary training course in Algeria.

He was eventually arrested, and after a nine month trial was found guilty in June 1964 for his part in initiating a grand scheme of sabotage and for the violent overthrow of the South African Government. Even his lawyers admitted that he was guilty of three of the four charges. He and seven others were sentenced to life imprisonment-a light sentence certainly by African standards.

The saboteurs were convicted of having 105 plans, including those for having foreign forces dropped on South African shores, and for targets to be sabotaged, including power stations, all means of communications, police stations and so on. In addition, plans to build an arsenal of 210,000 hand grenades, 48,000 land mines and some 50 tons of explosives were recovered-enough to wipe Johannesburg off the map.

At that time, Mandela had written a great deal about the virtues of communism and how to implement the communist system. Some of his writings would have done Lenin and Stalin proud. It is all on the record and mostly in his own handwriting for those who may doubt the claim. Of course, even as late as September 1985 Amnesty International affirmed that Nelson Mandela had participated in planning acts of sabotage and inciting violence and so could not be classified as a political prisoner.

Despite all this, I do not believe any reasonable person here would begrudge his being released. It was clearly the right decision at the time. We all truly hope he will be able to play a responsible part in the move towards a truly democratic South Africa. Nevertheless, though we are understandably tolerant of his statements there have been some wildly fluctuating messages coming forth. Even the day before he met George Bush he reaffirmed his support for the Palestine Liberation Organisation's Yasser Arafat, Cuba's Fidel Castro, and even Libya's Colonel Gaddafi. In the face of all this I hope de= Klerk's indulgence will not waiver, and that both Mandela and de Klerk can continue to work together for the greater good.

I do reiterate though, that the ANC is not the sole representative of black South Africa, far from it. We should also not forget that over two-thirds of the ANC's executive are also members of the South African Communist Party, including the notorious Joe Slovo who is a slavish advocate of the failed doctrines that have bankrupt and oppressed eastern Europe.

The ANC's so-called `Freedom Charter' supports a strong socialist agenda of nationalisation of property and industry, the same menu that has bankrupted Tanzania, Mozambique and so many other African countries. Surely that is the last thing we want for a new South Africa.

Rather than directing all their criticisms at the brave de Klerk, the rest of the world, Australia included, should be putting a bit of pressure on the ANC to reveal exactly what their economic formula is for a post-apartheid South Africa. If it is de Klerk who always has to make the concessions, with nothing ever to show for the ground he is giving, it will be so much harder for him to not only pacify the noisy right, but also allay the fears of the white middle classes. The world, by not requesting a balanced commitment from both sides, and by putting down or ignoring the majority black groups while at the same time elevating the minority ANC, is only making a satisfactory end result that much harder to achieve.

The situation is fragile and complex enough as it is, without the constant stream of unhelpful, ignorant and counter-productive nonsense that masquerades as policy forever pouring out of Australia. If we genuinely desire peace and democracy in that country and have the overall welfare of the black people at heart, then we must start to better inform ourselves of the situation over there and formulate our responses accordingly.

Normal trade should be resumed and reciprocal investment in both countries encouraged for the mutual benefit of both. As well, sporting contact should be allowed. The Gleneagles Agreement should be scrapped. The document is meaningless. Despite what most people think, the so-called `agreement' was never signed, let alone ratified. It only says, in effect, that each government, acting in a manner that it best thinks fit, should discourage all sporting contact between those countries, including South Africa, where sports are organised on the basis of race, colour or ethnic origin.

There are two further points about the agreement that are worth noting. Firstly, only a government can breach the Gleneagles Agreement, not an individual sportsperson or a sporting body as most believe. Secondly, it clearly says that all sporting contact is to be discouraged. There is no distinction whatsoever allowed to be made between teams or individuals, professionals or amateurs, national representatives or non-representatives, or between one sport and another. Our Government, quite mistakenly, has created these distinctions for its own convenience and so breaches the Agreement almost daily. Quite clearly, the document is a farce and should be rejected forthwith.

Most blacks are as opposed to sporting boycotts as they are to trade sanctions. This is not surprising. Their soccer players would love to play an international team, their boxers to fight overseas, their world class long distance runners to compete at the Olympics. How does our boycott help these black people? On the other side, show me a Maori rugby player who, given half a chance, would not want to play against the Springboks. Here is one avenue, one outlet, where blacks can equal and surpass their white Afrikaaner brothers, where they can become higher income earners, and where they can gather world accolades for their performances with all the reflected glory that will flow through to their impoverished brothers and children in black townships, thereby ultimately giving them a goal to strive for which they do not presently have.

Yet, divorced from them by the width of the Indian Ocean, never having asked their opinion and never even having been to South Africa to see what is going on there, we sanctimoniously and patronisingly deny them all this from our comfortable position. We say we know best, and the world is a lesser place for our attitudes. So let us resume this contact with South Africa. In that way we can both help and influence it more. I say to this Government by all means let us encourage de Klerk to talk to the ANC, but get some perspective into the scene instead of simply trying to pick who it would like to win just because he or she is a socialist.
